results.description:
Dear Friends:
  It’s getting exciting! The Phenomenon And The Gift course/retreat is happening in Boston and DC, Toronto and Orlando on Feb 27 and 28 with a pre-event on the 26th, it is hosted by Oneness Massachusetts and Oneness University of India

200+ people have registered for Boston so far—it will be AWESOME!
  Some of you have shared that you have some questions, which are addressed below. Also, check out comments from people like us who participated in CA (below)
  You still have time to register. 
  Love,
Marael

1. I am not familiar with Oneness University. Who is this seminar for?
This seminar is for everyone. It is for people from all walks of life: lawyers, business owners and professionals from very conservative backgrounds; spiritual people and non-spiritual people; people of all ages, backgrounds and approaches to life.
  If you are concerned that it is too spiritual—too woo-woo–it isn't. It is a very grounded, practical program taught in a western approach, which is completely in alignment with how we think. The teachings are simple, powerful and deep. 
  People from all over the world attend courses at Oneness University for a better life. This course allows all who come to experience major shifts that transform their life in a gentle yet powerful way—here at home. Whatever your path is, it will be strengthened.
  2. What are the teachings? Who will be giving them?
The teachings are simple, streamlined teachings—practical, the nuts and bolts—that are designed to help us raise our consciousness level. They will be delivered by story telling, exercises, reflection time and question and answer sessions.
  Oneness Guides who are in very high states of consciousness themselves will give the teachings. These guides have spent upwards of 20 years studying how to help people shift into higher states of consciousness. They have learned how to help us receive the transfers of grace necessary to enter into high states and then remain there. The guides are down-to-earth people, with a sense of humor and very high intelligence.
  3. Sounds like it could be boring watching a screen all day. What will it be like?
It is so dynamic! Those who have attended report it’s like you are transported to the Oneness University temple in India where people go into extremely high states of consciousness. You are transported in time and space. Energy and grace pours off the screen and bathes you all the time. It is such an interactive experience. You are interacting directly with the Guides—you can see them and they can see you. As well, you will see all the people in Toronto, DC and Orlando.
  4. What is "The Gift"?
People who come will experience a transformation in their life. It is totally dependent on what you want and what you ask for. This is “your” gift. You also receive a direct transfer of Grace to help you. You can share this transfer of Grace to help others when you leave the seminar. In that sense, it is “a gift that keeps on giving!”
  5. What do people who have participated say?
“I was completely new to Oneness. This program has had a huge impact on me and my work. My artwork is flying off the shelf—more wealth and prosperity is coming into my life. I was surprised how very practical and tangible the results have been.” — Artist 
  “I used to resist things, avoid things or use a lot of effort to get things done. During the course a shift happened.  Now it is effortless. I am easily able to stay present with what is. Miracles happen. This is such a gift!” — Mary
  “This course has helped me to feel safe! Now, I have a strong connection to my path.” —16 year-old girl.
  “This program has literally transformed my life! It is that powerful!” — Liliana
  “It is way easier to connect to my Inner Guidance. I trust it more! I get answers really quick now. I am able to hold centre when all around me is in chaos.” — Link

REGISTER NOW 

The weekend course is hosted by Oneness Massachusetts and takes place at the Boston Mariott Newton and in Toronto, DC and Orlando. For all the details and to register go to https://tickets.brightstarevents.com/event/ThePhenomenon 

If you feel a tug in your heart, follow up on it. Feel free to contact me for any questions. 

https://tickets.brightstarevents.com/event/ThePhenomenon
results.name: The Phenomenon And The Gift

ONE Cantonese Event each Friday evening - with SEVERAL ACCOMPLISHED Cantonese speakers/teachers/guides - at the Huntington Avenue YMCA/Hastings Hall - Room # 101

The ONLY entrance is at 320 Huntington Avenue.

The weekly Cantonese-English chat begins with a one-hour level 1 Cantonese language class followed by a free chat. 

<a href="https://www.google.com/maps/dir/">https://www.google.com/maps/dir/ - for Google Maps

Directions from YOUR starting point...

Until mid-April, Dandan's YMCA-based Cantonese-English class and chat will be in in Boston YMCA 101.

Dandan 'Danni' Mai and Xiao 'Cecelia' Xiu, from the PRC (and NEU), host these friendly meetups (in Boston YMCA 101), and Frankie Presta may also instruct.

* Cantonese speakers want to practice English (and reduce their Chinese accents)?  
* English speakers want to learn Cantonese?  
* Nerdy Chinese folks want to bring friends and have a fun, FREE "outing" in Boston just talking with nerdy strangers in English or Cantonese?

6:00 - 7:00PM - Cantonese class 
7:00 - 9:00PM - Bilingual free chat.

6:00 - 7:00 - 廣東話班
7:00 - 9:00 - 雙語談話

* Green Line E-Line comes above ground to Northeastern, and the YMCA is around the corner.
* Walking from the Orange Line takes about 5-10 minutes, walking through Northeastern University.
* Walking from Brookline is about 15 minutes.
* MFA, Wentworth, College, and Harvard's LMA are adjacent - on or off Huntington Avenue. 
* Route 9 comes near the area, via Brookline.

• Massachusetts Avenue stop on the Orange Line (then walk around NEC to YMCA).
• New England Conservatory stop on #39 bus

results.description:
We're back and planning a series of talks this year for the useR group. For February, we're excited to have Jan Vitek from Northeastern University give a talk.

Abstract:

This talk will summarize some of the recent work on improving performance of the R implementation, including the GNU R bytecode compiler, the Oracle FastR project and a research project at Northeastern that involves using the LLVM as a back end compiler for the language.  I will start by telling you what makes R not-fast and how to improve on the state of the art.
results.name: Jan Vitek - Getting R to run Fast

I have permission for us to do a series of Beginner Salsa Lessons. (swing lessons to follow if this is a success) I'll post 2 to start so please help me make these a success by giving it a shot. You'll have a blast trust me!


Our instructors have years of dancing experience, plenty of personality and of course I'll be providing the sound system with some great music. I've taken group lessons before and the music was too fast, esp in the open dance time. So we're going to gear this to 2 left footed neanderthal dancers like me.


The Hanson Rec Commission members are very excited about this and want us to succeed. So thank them when you see them at the event.


Our plan is to have weekly dances for 2 hours. The first hour will be a lesson and the 2nd an open dance. These will be geared for beginners so don't be afraid. To You Salsa veterans - please come because we'll need your help too... and you can show off during the open dance hour.


Once per month we'll be having a bartender for a 4 hour dance. A little wine might loosen up the hips a little ;-) This first dance will be for 2 hours. The 2nd dance lesson on Feb 26th will have the bar and be open for 4 hours. (7-11 see the post for the 26th)


Gender equity? of course ladies bring a man with you but for the first few lessons gender equity won't be a huge issue. Nevertheless, put the pressure on the men you know, in the group and out, to make it to this. It's gonna be a blast !

Please post questions below.

DIRECTIONS - Please use your GPS. For those of you who have never been, Hanson is only 30 min from Plymouth and Braintree. And only 15 min from Hanover or Brockton. See it's nice and centrally located. Camp Kiwannee is right on rt 58 with plenty of parking.

The cost is $10 per person - a very reasonable price. FYI - I don't make a dime on this. Camp Kiwanee gets a percentage of the door and the remainder goes to the instructors and those working the door.


Here's a few pictures of Needles Lodge at Camp Kiwanee. It's a gem right here in our little one-horse town of Hanson.

That's only about 2/3rds of the room. They were rehearsing a play in the other third. I'll get better pictures up there soon. But you get the idea.

the entrance... love this place... Old world charm...

results.description:
Each and every Friday, we're proud to open the doors of our music school in Central Square for a FREE seminar, demo or meet-up. Hell, we’ll even throw a classical music concert or two. What's in store this week? Let's find out:

So you've made your tracklist and checked it twice, and now it's time for your first professional gig. Mmmmaven's own Fens guides us through your first gig preparation check list and gives tales from the road of what to expect when you're stepping up for your first performance. Library management, professional etiquette, and other tips to help ensure that your first gig won’t be your last. Be sure to swing by for this free workshop and strengthen your DJ career beyond the booth.

Fens is a resident DJ at Shake!, a monthly party held at Goodlife. He is also the co-founder of the now defacto Banana Peel Records, formerly of JASS, and MMMMaven. He DJs, and has also been fortunate to have played at venues such as Middlesex Lounge, House of Blues, Le Poisson Rouge, Goodlife, Enormous Room, Middle East Downstairs, Fenway Park, RISE, among others, as well as having shared the booth with DJs like Machinedrum, Objekt, Pangaea, L-VIS 1990, SBTRKT, Christian Martin, DJ Assault, Tevo Howard, Incyde, Tittsworth, Battles, Ghostland Observatory and many more.

Free Friday Workshop
Preparing for Your First Gig
Friday February 26th
614 Massachusetts Ave. #203
7pm/Free
results.name: Preparing for Your First Gig [2/26 #FREE]

results.description:
• THE BOSTON DRUM CIRCLE

• A high-energy, FUN, celebration of drumming and community. For beginners who want to try something new, their friends, experienced drummers, dancers beginners to experts. NO EXPERIENCE REQUIRED!

• We celebrate the traditions - rhythms that have built energy for hundreds of years for celebration, dance, ritual - just plain FUN! As well as whatever you bring to it!

• We gather together every other Friday evening. Check the schedule, grab your drum (or use ours) and have a blast!

We'll have drums to share, and support for newcomers, and energy for everyone.

Recent accolades!

“Great fun! Good rhythms. Very accommodating leader and group for this beginner. Will be back!”

Adrienne S 10/14

It was an amazing experience .. It was nice to feel free from the world and it's problems .. It's was so relaxing, can't wait to drum again ..thanks!

Justin 6/14

Was an awesome experience, I love hand drumming but really the main reason I came was to relieve stress due to family health situations and the circle definitely met my needs. Alan did a great job leading the circle with the drumming and the short history lessons about drumming and Africa. I will be coming back.

Paul 10/13

This Drum Circle is a great stress reliever after a long week of work and I wish it were every Friday night!! Boston Drum Cirlce attracts a wonderful , eclectic group of people that share the common bond of hand drumming. It is always wonderful to have the multi talented Fanta leading the Circle. Her singing, dancing, and drumming are all 5 star. Thank you for a great night of Drumming!

Carla 8/13

We can't wait to meet you! See you soon....

Alan and Fanta

venue.name: Harvard Film Archive

results.description:
La chute de la maison usher

Directed by Jean Epstein. With Marguerite Gance, Jean Debucourt, Charles Lamy
France 1928, 35mm, b/w, 61 min

Live Musical Accompaniment by Martin Marks


Long considered a masterpiece of French impressionist cinema, The Fall of the House of Usher’s uncanny camera effects now seem closer in spirit to the symbolist poets than the impressionist painters. Drawing upon the full raft of avant-garde strategies prescribed in his theoretical writings, Epstein evokes the frenzy of artistic obsession, the transcendental force of nature, and the inherently subjective nature of appearances. Poe’s motif of a painting so startlingly lifelike that it saps its real subject provides Epstein with an ideal vehicle for his ontological preoccupations with cinema itself. As Epstein would later reflect of the film’s mesmerizing use of slow motion, “The actor can usually perform anything: he comes in, sits down, opens a book, flips through the pages; only the camera gives him a profound gravity, burdens him with an inexplicable secret and makes him a fragment of tragedy through the simple reduction of the temporal ratio of this performance.” Print courtesy Cinémathèque Française.

Preceded by

The Three-Sided Mirror 


(La glace à trois faces) 

Directed by Jean Epstein. With Jeanne Helbling, Suzy Pierson, Olga Day
France 1927, 35mm, b/w, silent, 38 min. French intertitles with English subtitles

With its strikingly modernist approach to film narrative, The Three-Sided Mirror set the template for innumerable puzzle movies to come. Three women from distinct milieus narrate their failed romances with the same doomed lothario. The film’s gender politics are every bit as audacious as its fragmented narration and overlapping temporalities, with each undermining any notion of a stable personal identity. At a stylistic level, The Three-Sided Mirror is suffused with the kinds of kinetic thrills and visual detailing advocated in Epstein’s writings: an exquisitely rendered telephone call, a reckless drive through a parking garage and the integration of documentary material in a carnival sequence. Print courtesy Cinémathèque Française.

See you at the movie,

John

results.description:
Here's the game plan:

7:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

7:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

7:20 - Play!!!!!!

9:00 - Conclude the meetup and begin socializing.

Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white and a dark-colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a light or dark "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!

Cost is $10. Please make sure to have exact $10 bills - Cash Only, as there will not be much change. Credit Cards will NOT be accepted, so please come prepared. Thanks!

For more information, please visit their website at:
www.dodgeballofboston.com

PS: Ideally it is great to come on time, but if you do arrive late(Asian time), no worries. We will be playing until 9:30pm at least. But you'll just have less playing time, so please arrive on time if you can. See you guys soon!

results.description:
Join us for our monthly Kabbalat Shabbat celebration at the historic Vilna Shul. This month we welcome David Gerzof Richard, founder and president of BIGfish Communications and co-founder of Havurah on the Hill. 

David Gerzof Richard is the founder and president of BIGfish Communications, a public relations and marketing agency that works with disruptive innovation and technology companies. Over the past 16 years, David has successfully developed and executed numerous award-winning marketing, PR and social influence campaigns for a broad range of clients. In 2003, David was appointed a professor at Emerson College where he currently teaches a range of marketing courses and serves as Communication Scientist under the Communication Studies Chairman. He appears regularly on NPR's national broadcast of On Point with Tom Ashbrook and contributes to a variety of national online, print and broadcast news outlets. David can be found on Twitter @DavidGerzof and online atwww.BIGfishPR.com

Schedule of Events:
6:30 PM Wine and Appetizers
7:00 PM Shabbat Services
8:15 PM Discussion with Featured Speaker
8:45 PM Kosher Buffet Shabbat Dinner
(vegetarian and gluten free options available)

Suggested donation $10.00 per person.

results.description:
Come and join us for an evening of fun and shared energy. How often do we get an opportunity to be real with each other in Boston?

At TurnON, we play three communication games (just talking, no touching), and you can participate at whatever level feels good to you. Imagine meeting new people in an environment where they feel comfortable to express themselves and challenge the edges of their comfort zones; a refreshing change from the typical networking or bar conversation. That's what we have created.

TurnON events give you the opportunity to look deeper into yourself, through other people putting quality attention on you, asking questions with genuine curiosity, and then listening - really listening – to your responses. What comes up might surprise you!

It's amazing how connected we can end up feeling - even in a room full of strangers - when we are willing to be authentic. It's like a giant exhale when the rest of the world is asking you to hold it in. In just an hour, you may even forget that you are in Boston.

TurnON Boston is an organization that teaches Orgasmic Meditation, otherwise known as OM. The games we play at TurnON events are designed to create the visceral sensation of Orgasm/OM in your body, without actually doing the practice. At the end of the evening, we will give you a brief description of the practice of OM and information on how to learn more.

$10, payable at the door.

Please arrive on time - we lock the door promptly at 7:40!

Limited non-resident parking is available alongside our building on Dudley Street, or plentiful metered spaces on Mass Ave are only one block away (and free after 6pm). We are a 10-minute walk from the Red Line at Davis Square. http://tedxtalks.ted.com/video/TEDxSF-Nicole-Daedone-Orgasm--2
results.name: TurnON Boston

results.description:
Let's Play Dodgeball!

Remember when you used to get a lunch break AND recess? Let'slationships were formed while we were playing games-we made friends, scores were settled, and we figured out how to interact with the opposite sex. Well, some of us did :)

https://youtu.be/QPDs4zs3kzw

Remember when you used to get a lunch break AND recess? Let's return to our glory days for some school yard fun! So many relationships were formed while we were playing games-we made friends, scores were settled, and we figured out how to interact with the opposite sex. Well, some of us did :)

Worried about being branded with the logo from the rubber ball? Well, don't...we use soft squishy balls…without a visible logo :) So, if you really hope to get a tattoo, you'll have to find another way.

Dodgeball Details: Teams are chosen round robin style, so it doesn't matter if you ruled the schoolyard at one point. There won't be any awkward "I hope I'm chosen before the kid in the full body cast". The "rules" will be explained by the referee before playing starts. They aren't complex, and there won't be any instant replays for controversial calls.

It's designed to be fun, playful, and casual. The only rule I can remember is not aiming for someone's head. Ladies, I can't guarantee that the guys are going to follow that one : ) Guys, this is still not the best way to get a woman's attention….

All levels are welcome! We will be playing on a padded floor, wearing socks (remember to bring socks!). The arena is air conditioned and is smaller than a typical dodgeball court. There are two individual bathrooms that some people change in. Some people come prepared to play, while others change.

Dodgeball of Boston is located at 1 Broadway in Arlington, MA. There is a small parking lot, emphasis on small, and free street parking available on the side streets. Public transportation is probably the easiest way to get there. It's about one mile from Davis Sq Redline T and Alewife T Stations.

Cost: $10. PLEASE try to pay with a $10 bill, or some combination that adds up to $10 ($5 bills, $1 bills, etc…), as change is hard to make. The cover goes to pay the rent for the space.

After Dodgeball: We will head for drinks/appetizers/Karaoke nearby at:

Orleans Restaurant 
65 Holland Street 
Davis Square, Cambridge

We always have a lot of fun there too, drinking, eating and singing karaoke, and it's a great way to enjoy Friday night!

This will be a joint event with other meet up groups, please only RSVP in one group.

IMPORTANT: Be sure to bring socks with you in order to play and no $20 bills please!

--Carla & Matt 
;-)

https://youtu.be/cXmt_iFLd58
results.name: Dodge The Ball! - Play Dodgeball With Us!

Cost: $10 (cash) which is paid when you arrive. Then after the game we head over to Orleans (65 Holland street) for cocktails. There is plenty of parking at both places.

results.description:
Come and join us for an evening of fun and shared energy. How often do we get an opportunity to be real with each other in Boston?

At TurnON, we play three communication games (just talking, no touching), and you can participate at whatever level feels good to you. Imagine meeting new people in an environment where they feel comfortable to express themselves and challenge the edges of their comfort zones; a refreshing change from the typical networking or bar conversation. That's what we have created.

TurnON events give you the opportunity to look deeper into yourself, through other people putting quality attention on you, asking questions with genuine curiosity, and then listening - really listening – to your responses. What comes up might surprise you!

It's amazing how connected we can end up feeling - even in a room full of strangers - when we are willing to be authentic. It's like a giant exhale when the rest of the world is asking you to hold it in. In just an hour, you may even forget that you are in Boston.

TurnON Boston is an organization that teaches Orgasmic Meditation, otherwise known as OM. The games we play at TurnON events are designed to create the visceral sensation of Orgasm/OM in your body, without actually doing the practice. At the end of the evening, we will give you a brief description of the practice of OM and information on how to learn more.

$10, payable at the door.

Please arrive on time - we lock the door promptly at 7:40!

Limited non-resident parking is available alongside our building on Dudley Street, or plentiful metered spaces on Mass Ave are only one block away (and free after 6pm). We are a 10-minute walk from the Red Line at Davis Square. http://tedxtalks.ted.com/video/TEDxSF-Nicole-Daedone-Orgasm--2
results.name: TurnON Boston

results.description:
FAQs about Japa

What is Japa?

The Sanskrit word Japa means “to utter softly” and is a powerful method of meditation using Mantra (sound) in repetitive recitation.

What is the Purpose of Japa?

Japa, as a spiritual practice, uses sound vibration to transform the physiological and psychological make-up and nature of the practitioner. Increasingly studies are attesting to the powerful effects sound vibration has on our physical and emotional well-being. What is a Mantra?

Mantra, which means “that which saves the mind” or “instruments of the mind”, is a collection of mathematically precise and melodic Sanskrit sound vibrations designed for specific energetic intentions.

Why is the Maha Mantra called the “great” Mantra?

This specific Mantra deemed “great” for two reasons: 1) it is one of very few mantras that combines both the feminine and masculine divinities simultaneously. 2) It can be chanted at any time and place.

What is the origin of the Maha Mantra?

This Mantra is found in the Kali-santara Upanishad, one of the 108 principle Upanishads, and was given by Brahma to the sage Narada.

What are the benefits of Japa Meditation?

Because the Maha Mantra combines both the feminine and masculine it is a Bhakti mantra or “mantra of loving relationships”. This works on transforming and improving the practitioner’s relationships on three levels - 1) Personal (relationship with oneself); 2) Interpersonal (relationships with others); and 3) Spiritual (relationship with the divine). Why Japa Circles?

Japa Circles provide a powerful space in which the simultaneous recitation by all members amplifies the energy of the mantra exponentially. What takes place at a Japa Circle?

For 15 minutes the practitioner fills out a four question survey and performs breathing and mindfulness exercises. For 30 minutes the actual Japa meditation takes place. Practitioners recite the mantra softly in rhythm and cadence with the instructor with increasingly relaxation and joy. The final 15 minutes is used for the concluding breathing exercises.

What is the purpose of the Survey?

Japa Circles and the various level s can only measure quantity of a practitioner’s Japa meditation. The purpose of the survey, which is private and for the practitioner’s personal use only, is to help measure the quality of a practitioner’s Japa meditation. What is the purpose of the various levels?

The Maha Mantra was handed down with a recommendation that the practitioner recite the mantra 35 million times! The various levels are designed to give us impetus and inspiration. However, in the more mature stages of our personal development these levels become superfluous as the joy and transformation awakened by our Japa meditation becomes its own reward.
results.name: Japa (Mantra Meditation) Class

results.description:
Friday nights are generally for more experienced students, as we work through some different parts of Fiore's works in a more open format.  New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (c[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

results.description: BG 1.40 - Just as misogyny has polluted every aspect and facet of human society spirituality has not been spared its insidious and destructive influence. In the Gita both Krsna and Arjuna unequivocally and soundly discredit misogynistic ideas and philosophies that have crept into and distorted pure spiritual teachings. In this class we will come to understand the critical importance of the feminine, and women in particular, in spiritual development as described by the Gita.

results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]

=====


Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike to two of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Galehead and Garfield. We will use Gale River Trail to reach (closed for season) Galehead Hut from where we will do the quick up and back to the summit. From there we will traverse the Garfield Ridge Trail and do the steep climb up to Garfield. We will turn around there and use the Mount Garfield Trail to get back down - because the roads are closed there are road walks of about 1.5 miles at both ends of this hike.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

RSVPs close 24 hours before the event.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 10 people. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you. 

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 17 miles (this include the 3 miles of road walking) and climb about 4,200 feet. It should take an average hiker about 9 hours 45 minutes to complete (this duration does not include time for breaks). This event is considered ADVANCED because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/44-Mt-Galehead-4024


• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/17-Mt-Garfield-4500


Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants. 

Use this link for the current weather forecast:

• http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.18700724100046&lon=-71.61091796099964#.Vp1QyzawlrU

=== What to Bring === 

Don't wear ANY cotton - this includes your socks and underwear. You will need winter hiking boots - if you wear them in the summer they aren't designed for winter use (e.g. insulation). You will need mountaineering snow shoes. Not all snowshoes are the same - some are designed for steep terrain with potentially deep snow while others aren't. These are the acceptable brands and models:

• Tubbs Flex ALP, Flex VRT, Flex TRK, or Mountaineers.

• MSR Lightening, Revo, or Evo. 

• TSL Symbioz Elite or Expert. 

• Atlas Aspect, Endeavor, or Series 10/11/12.

You will also need traction - while you can bring mountaineering crampons if you want I think all you will need is either Kahtoola Microspikes or Hillsound Trail Crampons. DO NOT BRING IMITATION SPIKES OR ANY FORM OF YAK TRAX.

Use this link for a list of items needed for a winter day hike: 

• </a><a href="http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf">http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet at the small parking lot at the intersection of Route 3 and Trudeau Road, which is directly across from the north entrance to Gale River Road south of Twin Mountain. According to Google Maps this spot is about 146 miles from Boston and it should take about 2 hours 20 minutes to drive there.

Use this link to customize the driving directions:

• https://goo.gl/maps/SisHTRxWDZq

</a>

While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the <a href="http://www.hikesafe.com/">Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

results.description:
Their major issue is that they have tons of donations, and not even close enough amount of volunteers, to sort useable vs. recycle goods.  

http://thewishproject.org/ 

The Wish Project is a non-profit dedicated to providing free furniture, home goods, baby goods, and clothing to people in need in the Merrimack Valley, primarily through reuse and recycling. They serve thousands of people each year, and rely on the help of many volunteers. Let's be some of those volunteers! We'll take on whatever task they need on this day, but generally it involves sorting and organizing donations so they can be given out to clients. Children ages 8+ are welcome to join the effort. It's a great opportunity to teach your kids compassion in a very hands-on way. 

IMPORTANT:

If you are bringing children, please make a note in the comments section so I can give the Wish Project an accurate count of adults and kids who will be attending.

http://thewishproject.org/

 *PLEASE NOTE:  When you RSVP 'yes' it becomes a commitment. I am in contact with the volunteer coordinator, Patty, whom is now a member, giving her a head count. She then creates a list of things that need to be done -relying upon the number of volunteers. If your plans change, please be considerate -take a moment to update your RSVP to 'no.' It's very simple- and greatly appreciated! Thanks :)

results.description:
Volunteer @FPR in John Eliot Square, Roxbury for $2 Bag of Vegetables
or get a $2 Bag for yourself just by showing up as 'an interested customer'

Fair Foods of Dorchester (FairFoods.org) delivers fresh (rescued) produce to about 60+ sites (only some are made public and publicized), and they hope to add MORE sites.  http://FairFoods.org/dollarbag.html

Usually (but not always), each site is hosted by a local organization (mostly nonprofits, but some are for-profit residences).

Each site needs unpaid volunteers to help
(a) unload the truck(s),
(b) set up the tables and produce (in order by weight, from heavy to light), and
(c) bag the produce into standard bags, which each sites 'neighbors' will come by (during the 'open' period) and take for $2/bag.

Most (but not all) sites get freshly-baked bread (baked fresh that morning).

Volunteers get to take home one or two (or more) bags of produce for themselves and 1-2 loaves of bread, also - because they volunteered.

To volunteer, in-mail the Meetup event host and say specifically which site and which date and time interests you (so that you can be registered in advance as a volunteer). In that in-mail, please provide your ACTUAL e-mail address, real full name, and phone number.

Please bring lots and lots of extra used but clean and reusable plastic bags for the bagging.


Bring with you some means for transporting home with you your own 'comped' produce (backpack/s, cloth shopping bag/s, duffel bag/s).
results.name: Volunteer @FPR for $2 Bag of Vegetables - or get a $2 Bag for Yourself

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

results.description:
Community Servings is a not-for-profit food and nutrition program providing services throughout Massachusetts to individuals and families living with critical and chronic illnesses. They give clients, their dependent families, and caregivers appealing, nutritious meals, and send the message to those in greatest need that someone cares. Their goals are to help clients maintain their health and dignity and preserve the integrity of their families through free, culturally appropriate, home-delivered meals, nutrition education, and other community programs.

Volunteers will be preparing and packaging meals for critically ill clients. This is anything from washing, peeling and chopping vegetables to packaging soups, salads, entrees and desserts. All new kitchen volunteers will be given an orientation during the first half an hour of the shift where the Community Servings staff will go over who they are, what they do, the impact of their service and safe food-handling policies!

Community Servings is minutes away from the Stony Brook station on the MBTA Orange Line. There is also a small parking lot available.

For more information, please check out the Community Servings official website: http://www.servings.org/
results.name: Prepare Meals at Community Servings

results.description:
Ever wanted to master studio lighting? 

Want to know the pitfalls and tips and tricks that will have you taking stunning studio photographs in no time at all?

There is money to be made from head-shot and studio portraiture but the chance to try out your skills and learn from an expert is not often afforded. Here is your chance to rectify that by becoming  part of a small select group of students as we spend a day exploring and learning about studio lighting with professional photographer, Ian Murray.

The class is suitable for photographers who have mastered the basic controls on their camera and are comfortable adjusting aperture and shutter speed.  It is not suitable  for absolute beginners.

We will cover

Single Light portrait setups

Use of reflectors

Two light "Clamshell" lighting

Use of Speedlights to create a perfect lighting set-up

Use of Studio Strobes and remote triggers.

Key Lights-hair lights

Creative backlighting with Gels

Color,  and Black and white, portraiture techniques

Re-creating a holywood portrait

The day will run from 10am to 3pm with a one hour break for lunch. Lighting and equipment will be provided - just bring your own camera and a packed lunch. 

The group will be limited to 6 and the cost will be just $95.
results.name: Introduction to Studio Lighting - one day workshop

Join me for a winter hike around the Greenways conservation area in Wayland. I picked this property because it should allow for a relatively easy hike given the variable conditions we get this time of year. 

http://www.sudburyvalleytrustees.org/sites/default/files/property/map/greenways.pdf


Micro spikes and poles are strongly recommended.

Please bring water.

Winter boots or hiking boots - no sneakers.

No dogs allowed on the hike.

I don't know the exact trail conditions but given the crazy weather I expect we will run into ice, snow and mud.


We will head to a Conrad's in Sudbury for lunch following the hike. 120 Boston Post Road, Sudbury (Route 20).

DIRECTIONS TO THE GREENWAYS


From the intersection of Routes 126 and 27 (near the Wayland Public Library) go south, crossing Route 20 and continuing nearly 1 mile. After passing Sandy Burr Country Club take the right turn onto Green Way, directly opposite St. Ann’ s Church. Once on Green Way bear right at the green “Traditions of Wayland” sign, and continue downhill 0.2 mi to the cul-de-sac. Parking is near the informational kiosk. 

Please Read The Fine Print: 

Duration: Approximately 1 1/2 - 2hours for the hike. However, any time estimate given is just that. Actual times vary greatly according to weather, trail conditions and the group itself.  I am not responsible for getting you back in time for later in the day plans. There is no way of knowing trail conditions ahead of time. Use your own judgment. Anyone with recurrent "No Shows" or about whom we have received complaints from fellow hikers will not be accepted. Please don't RSVP "Yes" unless you really intend to come. I am committed to being there for you. If you are not equally committed to being there, then please don't sign up.

This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the lead, stay together, stop at junctions and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own. We hike in light rain or showers, but heavy rain, snow or extreme cold weather cancels. Bring water, hiking boots or sneakers, bug spray, snacks and any personal medicines. Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

Please remember that I am a volunteer, the event is free, and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you are expecting Daniel Boone as your leader you will be very disappointed. If you need everything to run perfectly, this hike is not for you.


By clicking the "Yes" option on the RSVP link you are agreeing to the Liability Waiver as stated below:  Remember: I am a volunteer. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you have read and agree to adhere to the safety standards detailed @ http://www.hikesafe.com/; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason.

results.description:
Are you Separated or Divorced, Considering Divorce, Or Currently in the Process of Divorce? Please join us for Divorce 101: Retirement and Financial Planning - How to plan for your finances during divorce discussions and afterwards. 

This is a multi-group event listed on other meetups, so attendance will be greater than the RSVP's on this meetup alone.

This event is intended to be partly informational, partly social, and totally empowering. Attendance to this event and information shared will be kept confidential.

Speakers: Robert Vona & Samantha Steer of Centinel Financial Group, LLC

Topic: Divorce brings unique challenges to financial planning. Learn about the financial and emotional implications of the outcome of your divorce. Additionally, learn about the strategies for moving forward with your new life financially. Bob and Samantha work particularly with people going through separation and divorce and will share their knowledge of the options you have.

At this event, there will be a chance to socialize with other attendees and speak one-on-one with Bob and Samantha as well as the other professionals:

Jim Brennan of Maritime Mortgage

Sheila May, CPA and Forensic Accountant

Kimberly Keyes, Divorce Attorney

There is no cost for attendance. Complimentary refreshments and snacks will be provided.

Note that this Divorce 101 event will also be held at the same location on Thursday February 25th, from 6:30 to 8:30 p.m. (Meetup event listed separately).

Similar Divorce 101 events at this location will be held every month on the fourth Thursday and fourth Saturday. Please check the calendar for these upcoming events:

• Thursday, March 24 & Saturday, March 26, 2016; Divorce 101: Taxes and Divorce -- Before you settle, know the tax implications and plan for what to do after the divorce

• Thursday, April 28 & Saturday, April 30, 2016 (5th Saturday this month); Divorce 101: How to approach dating again and in the online context – set up a profile and manage responses

• Thursday, May 19 & Saturday, May 21, 2016 (3rd Thursday & Saturday this month, because of Memorial Day); Divorce 101: The House -- Should you try to keep it or sell it; what to consider

Join us for the February 2016 Meetup!

ATC THEMES:


1. Poetry quote


2. Artist's Choice (anything goes)


DEMO/ACTIVITY: Artzster (game-based approach to creating, lots of fun); making backgrounds.


WHAT OTHER SUPPLIES SHOULD I BRING? There's a suggested list in "All About the NE ATC+ Meetup" (also at the top of the Message Board). But even if you show up empty-handed, that's fine--we have loaner tools.

POTLUCK LUNCH: You're invited, but certainly not required, to bring food or drink for our potluck lunch, or to just bring your own lunch. No need to sign up; bring whatever you like. Please remember that you must take, give away, or throw away any food you bring; we can't leave ANYTHING behind.

FREE STUFF/SALE ITEMS: You're welcome to bring items to give away or sell to other Meetup members onsite. But anything that doesn't get taken or sold needs to go home with you. 

COST: $10, regardless of when you arrive or depart; it covers our costs for the day. Sorry, no partial payments or IOUs. Cash is preferred; small bills are greatly appreciated. You can break large bills in businesses on Route 135 near the church. If payment is a hardship, please let the organizer know--we can work it out.

RSVPs: Please RSVP "yes" to attend; that way, we'll have an approximate headcount, and you'll receive all notifications about the Meetup! If your plans change, and you will be unable to attend, please change your RSVP to "no" no later than 24 hours before the start of the Meetup, so we'll know not to expect you. Anyone who cancels within 24 hours, regardless of the reason, will need to pay the fee anyway to help cover our costs for the day. 

LAST-MINUTE UPDATES: Please check your email in box and the website before leaving for the Meetup. That way, in the unlikely event that we need to cancel due to bad weather or any other reason, you'll be sure to get the news.

Hope to see you there!

results.description:
In this Develop Module intensive Adobe Certified Expert, Kathy Tarantola, will cover many of the features that make Lightroom an amazing and powerful processor of digital images.

We will learn how to evaluate your photographs and how to make creative processing decisions with time to practice each step. Using your own images with help along the way, you will walk away with hands-on knowledge and the confidence to enhance all of your work quickly and with stunning results.

Topics include
• Perfecting tone and color in each photo
• Applying sharpening and noise reduction
• Correcting lens distortion and chromatic aberration
• Noise Reduction
• Cropping
• Spot, Red Eye, Graduated and Radial Filter, Paintbrush tools
• Hue, Saturation, Luminance, adjustments
• Using virtual copies to create variations of your work
• Post crop vignetting and the dehaze filter• Making great black and white conversions
• Creative presets – use LR templates or create your own
• Soft Proofing for printing

Our purpose in teaching module specific workshops is to have each student learn features in depth and to leave the workshop with a true understanding of the how the program can enhance your images and ease your workflow.

Date: Saturday February 27, 2016 
Time: 12-5 PM 
Location: Digital Silver Imaging, 9 Brighton St. Belmont, MA 

There is Fee for this course of $149

Click here to enroll and pay for this workshop

results.description:
In the Heat of the Night is a 1967 American mystery drama film directed by Norman Jewison. It is based on John Ball's 1965 novel of the same name which tells the story of Virgil Tibbs, a black police detective from Philadelphia, who becomes involved in a murder investigation in a racist small town in Mississippi. It stars Sidney Poitier, Rod Steiger, and Warren Oates, and was produced by Walter Mirisch. The screenplay was by Stirling Silliphant. The film won five Academy Awards, including the 1967 award for Best Picture.

Detective Tibbs is caught up in the racial tension of the US South when he is arrested after the murder of a prominent businessman. Tibbs was simply waiting for his next train at the station in Sparta, Mississippi and the confusion is soon resolved but when local police chief Gillespie learns that Tibbs is the Philadelphia PD's number one homicide expert, he reluctantly asks for his assistance.


This program is sponsored by the Friends of the Thomas Crane Public Library.
results.name: Classic Film Series: In the Heat of the Night

Hi All,

This meetup will be a departure from our usual sketching format. We will be meeting at Diesel Cafe to have a short sketching session, about an hour or so, and then head to Nave Gallery Annex to see their 2016 Sketchbook Show! 

Diesel cafe is a coffee shop/gallery in Davis square with motor themes. Once a declining neighborhood, a burgeoning art scene started and has now made Davis Square one of the trendy neighborhoods to live in. Around the corner is Nave Art Gallery. The Gallery has been the public face of ARTSomerville, a nonprofit, loosely knit volunteer group of artists and arts enthusiasts with the mutual goal to create new space(s) to present art in Somerville.

More information about the show can be found on their website. http://navegallery.org/wp/the-sketchbook-show-2016/ 

So come join us for a coffee, sketching, and gallery viewing!

-Miriam

results.description:
We're doing a fun 10-week training program! All levels are welcome, and you don't need to be able to make it every week. In week 1, we timed ourselves in a few key events (e.g. 100 freestyle), and now we're doing a training program to get ourselves faster. At the end of 10 weeks we'll time ourselves again and see how much we've improved! If you can't make a week, don't worry, you can still come to the other weeks.


The 10 weeks will include clinics on technique, flip turns, and any special requests, as well as some good sets to get us swimming faster. If there's a race you're targeting and want to work on that distance or event, let us know and we can help tailor the workouts for you.

We go across the street for pizza (or other food if you don't eat pizza) every week after the swim. Save time to join us! We usually finish up by about 4:30pm.


---------------


The pool opens at 2pm, so we meet to go in at 1:45 so that we can be out on the pool deck by 2. $6 to get in, Cambridge residents $5 (or you can buy a 10-pack for an approximate 10% discount, and we do these weekly so you'll have the opportunity to use them up).

Street parking is available but stressful, and the 69 bus drops off down the block, or you can bike or run there and do 2/3 of a triathlon :)

results.description:
For the last couple of years, I have celebrated my birthday by having a big old blowout game day at my house. While Virgin Queen is probably over-ambitious for my current lifestyle, I would still like to kick off another trip around the sun with some gaming goodness. And, furthermore, because I have a screwed-up idea of what constitutes a "fun party game," I'd like to take this chance to play a game of the sort that doesn't get played on a regular weekday night -- even if it's not one of my beloved Reformation-era dicefests. Some prime examples from my collection:

18xx (I have 1830, 1856 and 18AL)
Game of Thrones
Indonesia
Die Macher
Maria
Republic of Rome
Roads and Boats
Struggle of Empires
Successors
Sword of Rome
Triumph and Tragedy

Don't feel like you need to know the rules going in; it's pretty likely that whatever gets played is a learning game for someone.

Hopefully we can hash out what people want to play in comments. (I have my preferences, but I'd be fine with anything above.) We have enough table space to have two (maybe even three) games running in parallel so if people want to branch out to something not in my collection, I say go for it you mad dog. Space IS limited, however, I would gently ask those of you who might be interested but only in one or two specific games to hold off on RSVPing until you know there's a group committed to what you want.

Here's the gritty details:

1. As some of you are aware, we have a new tiny human at home. While she will be at an age when she's not quite so vulnerable to nasty illnesses brought by friendly strangers, it remains true that February is flu season and new babies with the flu are no fun for mom and dad, so we would like to politely but firmly request that you bow out if you've got flu symptoms or are very recently recovering, and that everyone take common-sense precautions like handwashing when you visit. We also have a cat at home, so people who are allergic should take precautions.

2. February is also snow season and while we're having a much more sedate winter than last year (knock on wood), if there is a big snowfall, the city can and will declare a snow emergency, which means no street parking. I'll try to keep everyone informed. We are accessible via several bus lines as well, so those who don't drive can get here. I'm happy to provide more specific advice on getting here for those who need it; don't be afraid to ask!

3. I will provide some snacks and drinks but I certainly encourage those who are inclined and able to bring something to share as well.

I think this will be a fun afternoon! I look forward to seeing everyone.

results.description:
Are you new to knitting, crochet, or needlecrafts? Want to work on your latest project with other progressive-minded crafters? Join us at the Panera Bread in Porter Square for Stitching for Justice on Saturday, February 27th from 2-5 pm! 

Crocheters, knitters, spinners, cross-stitchers, embroiderers and quilters are welcome, regardless of your skill level. 

So look no further if you're seeking like-minded folks to share patterns and techniques with, want to cross-promote your events and campaigns while you knit one purl one or finish off your latest granny square, or if you are new to the area and looking for groups to get involved in. 

Mind's Eye Yarns is right across the parking lot from our meeting place, so if you need more yarn or spinning fiber, or a new hook or needles for your latest project, you can easily pick up what you need on your way to Stitching for Justice.


If you want to build a strong cross-issue social justice movement, Socializing for Justice is for you. Arrive by yourself or bring a friend. Newcomers always welcomed.


Please note that this Panera is located in Porter Square shopping center. There is a large parking lot and it's very close to Porter Square T stop. Panera offers a wide variety of sandwiches, salads, baked goods and beverages (with free refills). Check out their menu. 


_________________________________________________________

SOCIALIZING FOR JUSTICE - www.sojust.org
SoJust is all about building a cross-cultural, cross-issue progressive community, network and movement in Boston based on the philosophy of abundance. We're doing it by putting the SOCIAL back in SOCIAL JUSTICE. We focus on creating welcoming spaces that foster relationship-building across issue silos.

SoJust isn't a non-profit 501(c)(3). We're a grassroots, volunteer-run, member-supported, cross-cultural, cross-issue progressive community that's been growing steadily since August 2006. We have 2800+ members, hosted over 200 events, and manage an online hub of progressive events and resources at www.sojust.org.

results.description:
During the 19th and 20th centuries, Boston’s free African American community led the nation in the movement to end slavery and to achieve equal rights. These remarkable patriots established businesses, founded organizations and created schools. Their houses of worship, homes, schools, and Underground Railroad sites make up Boston’s Black Heritage Trail.

The trail consists of 14 sites, beginning at the Robert Gould Shaw Memorial on Beacon Street and ending at the nation's first African Meeting House.

This is a family-friendly event.

For more information, visit http://www.afroammuseum.org/trail.htm or http://www.nps.gov/boaf/planyourvisit/hours.htm.
results.name: Walking Tour of the Boston Black Heritage Trail

results.description:
To me, photography is an art of observation. It's about finding something interesting in an ordinary place... I've found it has little to do with the things you see and everything to do with the way you see them.

Elliott Erwitt Photographer.

Learning to see creatively means slowing down to notice simple details right in front of you that have the potential to make a great photo. The things other people walk right by will suddenly jump out at you begging for your attention. 

When we travel, we tend to see our surroundings with a fresh eye. In this class we will develop the skill to see this same way where ever we are, even in our own city. Join some like minded folks to slow down and really see the beauty of Bostons North End.

Come discover the architectural details of the North End in Boston hidden in plain sight. You can make the ordinary extraordinary through your photography.

First, we will meet in front of Mike's Pastry and I will introduce you to some simple step by step practices for creative seeing so you can find beauty in the most unexpected places.

I have designed a series of 45 minute practices we will do together that will improve your composition, depth of field, and basic camera settings. Then you will have some time on your own to wander.

You will have a chance to try these out right away with my guidance.  You will receive individual coaching and critique while we are on the streets shooting. This way you can be confident that you will be able to repeat the process next time you are out on a shoot. This is a great session if you are interested in travel photography.

We will work with color, texture, pattern, and light to make our photos come to life. As always, this is a non technical jargon zone. It is all about the creative act of seeing and capturing the moments of life with a fresh eye.

I used the rule of thirds to compose this image. See how the subject fills 2/3 of the space and the background 1/3. WE will practice following and then breaking the rule of thirds to see how it impacts our photos.

In this image I have focused on the variety of textures and soft colors. Again I used the rule of thirds to compose the image and create dynamic tension. 

 I have found a fantastic area in the North End for our shoot. The winding streets are packed with interesting colors, reflections, architectural details, pipes, ghost signs.... all kinds of things you would never imagine would make great photo.

We will also spend one hour shooting just in black and white. This is a great way to develop an eye for detail and to balance your images with a full range of tones from pure white to black.  This photo was taken by Heather C. at a past North End Meetup. 

Nice black and white using strong composition to draw our eye into the frame. Photo by workshop participant: Bob Shook

Any camera is fine for this shoot. You can even use your iPhone if you like. This is a fun, fast paced workshop. So if you would like to meet other people who love photography and are curious about how to take better photos, I hope you will join us. After the photography class, you are invited to stay for social time and we will grab a slice of pizza a beer and take a look at our photos from the shoot to learn from each other.  Great way to spend Saturday evening!

The $45.00 tuition for the workshop is covered by my 100% SNAP HAPPY GUARANTEE.  If you are not happy with what you learn during the workshop, I will return your tuition to you on the spot.

The closest T stop is Haymarket on the Orange Line. There is a public parking lot at Haymarket. Then allow 15 minutes to walk to Mikes Pastry where we will start.

We are going to have a great time! You have joined the group, now join the fun. RSVP right away to hold your space. I look forward to seeing you This Saturday 2:30-5:30 

Suzanne

Last winter class in the North End! What a day. Should be warmer this time;)

Directions to the Ice Castles:
If you are traveling North or South on I-93:

Take Exit 33 on I-93,Continue on US-3 South.Take Connector Rd to Railroad St.

If you are in Lincoln, travel to Connector road and go west. The Ice Castles are a few hundred yards on the left.

Signs are placed between exit 33 and the Ice Castles directing you into the Ice Castles. Keep an eye out for these signs!

Please Note: GPS and other navigational aids do not always perform as they should in this area. In case of difficulties, please refer to the above directions.

Once you arrive, we will scan your ticket on your phone or off printed paper, either work great.

After your ticket is scanned, you will need to sign a paper acknowledging the rules inside the Ice Castles and accepting our Waiver of Liability. This is the same waiver you accepted when you purchased your ticket. After signing the Rules and Waiver of Liability form you may enter the Ice Castles.

http://icecastles.com/lincoln/


https://www.facebook.com/IceCastlesNH/posts/938855132888620
Come join me in the early evening hours for this spectacular site!
Who Makes the Ice Castles?

Ice Castles is a Utah-based company, led by ice architect Brent Christensen, which creates acre-sized, all-ice castles at venues across the United States. Over 500,000 guests have visited an Ice Castle since the company’s establishment in 2009.
Facts About Ice Castles

Each ice castle is built by hand and takes thousands of man-hours to create.
A team of 10-20 artists work day and night to build each ice castle by hand.
Ice castles use about 5 million gallons of water to build and maintain – every night 5-20 tons of ice is added as the castle gets watered and grows
All ice castles are located next to natural water sources so all of the water used returns directly to the environment
An ice castle spans about one acre
All of the lighting at the ice castle is frozen inside the ice – it makes for a surreal evening experience and during the day the ice takes on a glacial tone of deep blue Frozen wonderland returns to Lincoln, New Hampshire

This winter, Ice Castles, LLC will bring its popular attraction back to Lincoln, New Hampshire, as it unveils a massive castle made of ice. The acre-sized winter wonderland is crafted by hand using only icicles and water, and resembles organic formations found in nature, like those of frozen waterfalls, glaciers or ice caves.

Guests are invited to not only view the beauty of the structure but also to squeeze, squish and crawl through parts of the stunning, Narnia-like display. Favorite photo spots can be found in the throne room, in front of the waterfall and throughout the winding ice maze. Children will enjoy whizzing down the tubular ice slide and spelunking through small tunnels.

Ice Castles are the brainchild of ice artist Brent Christensen, who is bringing Ice Castles to New Hampshire for a second consecutive year. The Ice Castle features millions of icicles that sparkle a glacial blue by day and glow multi-colored at night with the help of thousands of LED lights embedded in the ice.

“Ice Castles are one of the most unique and beautiful places on earth,” said Christensen. “What’s really special is that every visitor gets a distinctive experience since the ice is constantly melting, freezing and being reshaped. It’s a continuously evolving and very interactive experience.”

Where: 64 Railroad Street, Lincoln, New Hampshire, 03251

When: Jan. 9 through March 2015, weather permitting

Hours: 2-9 p.m. Sunday-Thursday, 2-10 p.m. on Fridays, and noon-10 p.m on Saturdays

Tickets: General admission tickets for ages 12+ are $8.95 Monday-Thursday and $12.95 Friday-Sunday. For ages 4-11, tickets are $6.95 Monday-Thursday and $8.95 Friday-Sunday. Listed prices do not include taxes.

Discount: Senior, military and group discounts are available

Where to Purchase Tickets: Tickets can be purchased online.

Ice castles include ice tunnels, towers, caverns, canyons, archways and caves

There are plenty of things to do in the area aside from skiing, snow mobileing, flume ride and outlet shopping. So, make a day trip and end your evening at The Castles with me. :D
results.name: Ice Castles in Lincoln,NH

results.description:
To be a vegetarian is good for your body and soul! However, to be a well-informed vegetarian is even better. Let’s plan to read together great vegetarian books, watch movies/documentaries and, later, discuss them in a circle of vegetarian friends. Book selections will be recommended by a professional librarian or by you. Please provide me with your wish list of books that you want to read together as a group. We will plan to meet on a monthly basis.

Our January discussion went very well and we have even compiled a great book and movie wish list from the attendees. For our February discussion, we can either watch the documentary That Sugar Film (2015), read Salt Sugar Fat: How the Food Giants Hooked Us (2014), do both or simply show up to join in for a discussion over a cup of coffee, a tea, or a light meal.

About the Documentary:

That Sugar Film (2015) began as one man's journey to discover the bitter truth about sugar. Damon Gameau, who is a star and a director of this documentary, embarked on a unique experiment to document the effects of a high sugar diet on a healthy body, consuming only foods that are commonly perceived, or promoted to be 'healthy’. Through this entertaining and informative journey, Damon highlights some of the issues that plague the sugar industry, and where sugar lurks on the supermarket shelves. That Sugar Film will forever change the way you think about “healthy foods”.

About the Book:

Salt Sugar Fat: How the Food Giants Hooked Us (2014) by Michael Moss was named as one of the best books of the year by numerous magazines and newspapers. It is a #1 New York Times Best Seller and a winner of the James Beard Foundation Award for Writing and Literature.
From a Pulitzer Prize–winning investigative reporter at The New York Times comes the explosive story of the rise of the processed food industry and its link to the emerging obesity epidemic. Michael Moss reveals how companies use salt, sugar, and fat to addict us and, more important, how we can fight back.
results.name: Discussion of That Sugar Film and Salt Sugar Fat.

results.description:
Crystal Bowl Sound Immersion
w/ Laura Hackel
February 27th @ 6 – 7PM
$25 registration fee
http://yogaacton.com/crystal-bowl-sound-immersion/

Possibilities. You enter this life with so many of them. But then, somewhere along the way, you seem to have fewer and fewer of them. Your life can feel like a well-worn track. Where did all the possibilities go? They still exist, but beliefs, ideas and patterns acquired over a lifetime tend to bury them. Crystal Bowl Healings work to quickly shift your vibrational energy field and release whatever is limiting you; Whether it’s a belief that you have enough and it would be selfish to want more, or that you don’t deserve to have what you want in life.

As you sit or lay in a meditative state, I play the bowls, allowing the beautiful sounds and vibrations to work their magic in your energy field. The bowls play differently each time, affected by the energy in the room and what is needed to help you release old patterns.

By the end of the session, you will be ready for the new possibilities that are about to walk right into your life!

The crystal bowls are for you if you are:

Stuck in any area of your life
Wanting to experience more out of life but aren’t sure how
Experiencing self- sabotaging patterns
Wanting to make a change in life but aren’t sure how
Wanting to make changes at your own pace
Come discover the power of intentionally releasing and being open to what the universe is calling for you to bring into your life!

results.description:
Let's go to the sister bar to the World Famous Mr. Dooley's in Boston!  

Mr. Dooley’s in WRENTHAM has the inviting atmosphere and quaint bar - it has quickly become the "local" of Wrentham.

From its imported lace curtains to the family pictures on the wall, it is a warm and inviting atmosphere that gives you a glimpse into the feel of John Joe's local in his hometown of Finuge, Listowel, county Kerry. Focusing on traditional Irish comfort food, we have an expansive menu ranging from our Guinness steak tips to fresh New England seafood. Mr. Dooley’s has gained a reputation in excellence for food and service.

Mr. Dooley's also has MUSIC from Wed. thru Saturday ranging from an open mic night to traditional Irish music, something for everyone to enjoy.

Mr. Dooley's is a place to come and lay your hat and have a pint and a chat! Slainte!                               SOUNDS LIKE FUN!

DINNER MENU:  http://www.somerspubs.com/mr-dooleys/wrentham-menus/r-dinner.html

Please join the Red Sox Natives hosted by Bob at Laurie's 909 and others for the return of The North Avenue Band as they perform at Laurie's 9:09 on Saturday, February 27 after 7:00pm. The performance features all Classic Rock songs. For more info on the band go to http://www.northavenuebandwakefield.com.

We will be gathering near both the Penny Lane and Nickel Bars at Laurie's.

There is no cover.

The live performance will begin at approximately 7:09pm.

Stay for appetizers, dinner, a cocktail or two or three, socializing and more. If you have a group of people that want a table reservation for dinner please call Laurie's at[masked] and make a reservation. For information on Laurie's 909 and the menu go to www.lauries909.com.

Get there when you can and stay as long as you are able. You are more than welcome to show up for all or just part of the event.

If this will be your first time meeting the Red Sox Natives Crew check out the photos of those who RSVP Yes so you can find the group.

Please remember to maintain your own tab or pay as you order and tip your servers. However, if you sit at a group table a group bill may be provided so please communicate with your server when ordering. Credit Cards will be held by the servers at Laurie's.

Laurie's 909 is one of Wakefield's newest restaurant and Bar with live entertainment several nights per week along with many special E Mail promotions. Laurie's is located at the Wakefield Commuter Rail Train Station in Wakefield. The Reading and Haverhill Commuter Rail trains stop at Laurie's. Laurie's is easily accessible within 10 minutes from Routes 128, 93, 28 and 1. Free parking is available in two lots on Tuttle Street, in the Church parking lot if there are no activities there, and on street after 5:00pm. Check out the MBTA or Hop Stop for additional public transit options including the less reliable/frequent 136 and 137 bus lines.

More information at http://www.lauries909.com

See you there!

Both types of wines are made from the same grape but have a very different expression.  Barolos are bold with big tannins that are meant to age.  Barbarescos are more elegant and made to be drank younger. 


Joins us while we explore what makes Barolos and Barbarescos the wines that they are.

results.description:
Join us for an improntu dinner in celebration of our Independence!

Boston Dominican Professionals cordially invite you to our Dominican Independence Day Dinner to commemorate the 172nd  Anniversary of the Dominican Independence!

Although we will miss the carnival back in the island, we’ll celebrate with great Dominican food to bring back some good memories. We have made reservations at Merengue Restaurant, one of the most famous Dominican restaurants in the Greater Boston area.

Please plan to be there by 6:45pm, we’ll be seated at 7pm.

We are expecting a big group, I recommend bringing some cash to speed up the payment process at the end of the dinner.

Below is the link to the menu for your convenience.

http://themergepoint.com/files/Catering_Menu.pdf

Friends of friends are welcome!!! Please invite others, the more the merrier!!!

“Another culture is experienced upon entering the Merengue Restaurant.  Decorated with paintings by Dominican artists, and aromas of Caribbean spices all come together to create a small piece of the tropical nation. Owner Hector Piña, who first arrived from the Dominican Republic in 1986, says that he seeks to create a “grandma’s home” atmosphere.

He and his wife and co-owner Nivia want food at Merengue to resemble meals cooked by mothers and grandmothers in the tropics, with plaintains, yucca, rice and beans, tangy sauces, and lots of fish.

Proudly the couple attests to visits that such distinguished Dominicans as president Leonel Fernandez and slugger David Ortiz make on and off to the eatery.

Dominican cuisine is rooted in a mix of various cultures, including Spanish, Aztec (brought to the island by the Spanish from Mexico), African, and Mediterranean. The immigrants who first arrived to the island migrated with their own kitchen recipes and adapted foods and ingredients to resemble their cooking styles and tastes, according to Piña.”  - DominicanToday.com
results.name: Tonight: Improntu Dominican Independence Day Dinner

results.description:
One of my favorite bands Atlas Soul, has a show coming up this weekend, and should be pretty nice. Some of you may have seen them perform at the Bastille Day Block Party in Boston a couple years ago.

From the Regattabar Web Site:

"Atlas Soul is a multiple award-winning band performing original music that celebrates and blends spicy hot Afro-Mediterranean melodies and grooves with a generous dose of jazz, hip-hop, rock, and funk! Burning live performances with audience participation are their trademark! They have won or placed the Independent Music Awards four times - including the 2013 IMA vox poll in 2 categories - as well as winning accolades from many other music contests (too many to be listed here..) They have played scores of major venues such as The Montreal Jazz Festival, The Kennedy Center, The Festival International de Louisiane, the Boston Globe Jazz Festival, and more. They regularly sell out shows in the Boston area and beyond. Atlas Soul sings in French, Italian, Arabic, Hebrew and English, making their performances truly cross-cultural music experiences. The lyrics speak of love, ecology, oppression, happiness, immigration, poverty, spicy food... The band has produced five CDs: Chamsa, Mabrouka, Maktoub, Live@Regattabar, and Gypsy Wind. Atlas Soul's motto, world music for world peace, spells out its philosophical and political goal: to inspire world peace through a fusion of music and culture that gets people to the dance floor."

Tickets are $20. More info and tickets can be purchased here:

http://www.getshowtix.com/regattabar/moreinfo.cgi?id=3612

Regattabar typically seats by the order of ticket purchase, but I can request that we sit together ahead of time. If you would like to sit together, purchase your ticket and send me an email with your ticket order# by end of day Friday 2/26.

https://youtu.be/ggghMdYSHdA

results.description:
This event is cancelled for February. See everyone in March!

Join us for a monthly meetup to play some 18xx games.

Contact Dave M (click the link, then click "Message") for the address.

For the uninitiated, 18xx games are a subset of train games with a focus on stock-market and tile laying mechanics in the 19th century. Players start-up and manage (or mismanage…) railroads with the winning condition being money in the player’s hands at the end of the game. These games are all long, heavy, and feature little randomness leading many to consider them some of the most rewarding games to play. For more information please visit the wikipedia page at (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/18XX_games) or the BGG Wiki page at (https://boardgamegeek.com/wiki/page/18xx). You can find a version of the rules for 1830 on the mayfair website (http://mayfairgames.com/mfg-shop3/rules/MFG1830-Rules-V1_0.pdf) (focus on the 1830 classic rules) if you are interested in getting a head start.

For this meetup, we will try and get somewhere between 2-3 games in over the session. Players of all skill levels are invited to join us and we are happy to teach new players the system as well as teach new games in the system (I am still fairly new to the system myself).

PLEASE NOTE: Since the focus of this meetup is on longer games and the headcount limit is low (5 players/1 table) please be considerate when RSVPing for this event. Please try to give notice to those on the waitlist if you expect to have to drop your RSVP. Additionally, since there is only one table and the games are long, please try to arrive on time, since 1 person late will delay the whole group.

Please contact Dave M (click the link, then click "Message") for the address as well as any other information.
results.name: CANCELLED: Monthly 18xx in Waltham
