results.description:
Come join me for an evening of wine and share in some traditional Brazilian BBQ that I will prepare. Please bring a bottle of compatible wine in the $20 range in a paper wine bag, four glasses and $15 to contribute toward food. This will be a blind tasting.


 A brief history of Churrasco: In Brazil, churrasco is the term for a barbecue. Brazilian BBQ originally started in southern Brazil. A wide variety of meat is prepared and cooked on the BBQ grill. It is traditionally served on skewers. The traditional Brazilian BBQ is enjoyed over several hours which is perfect for a wine tasting event. We will taste the flights of wines and enjoy some delicious grilled meats, I hope you can join me while I share a part of my culture with you. I plan to prepare: white rice (arroz branco), bean casserole (feilao terpeiro), tomato sauce (vinegrete), fried cassava (mandioca frita), and for the meat we will have beef tenderloin, pork ribs, chicken wings, chicken wrapped in bacon, pork sausage and finally for dessert flan and rice pudding. Keep in mind that in traditional Brazilian BBQ the meat is the main course. I look forward to seeing what wines pair best with one of my favorite cultural dining experiences. Bring your appetites and Espero vê-lo lá (hope to see you there!)
results.name: Brazilian BBQ and Wine

- See more at: http://www.getshowtix.com/regattabar/moreinfo.cgi?id=3612#.dpuf
results.name: Regatta Bar ATLAS SOUL CONCERT

results.description:
By Jürgen Lobert and Lisa Ryan


This is part two of the Introduction to Night Photography series, where we will be focusing (!) on photographing the night sky, particularly stars. This is an intermediate to advanced lecture, recommended prerequisite for this lecture is that you either attended part I, the Introduction to Night Photography or you have at least experience shooting at night. Even though we will briefly go over basic settings again, we will not spend much time on that.

This event is for paid members only and it is a member benefit free of cost. If you haven't done so yet, please make sure to pay your membership online, there is a link to the left to do so. Any of these lectures will make your annual fee worth it.


The lecture will cover these topics:

Definitions
Equipment
Techniques
  Exposure settings
  White balance
  Darkness and Light pollution, where to shoot, light painting
  Focusing on stars, live demo
Types of astro-landscape photography
  Star trails: nature and urban
  Star points & Milky Way
  Clouds
  Moon
  Meteors
  Other atmospheric phenomena like zodiacal light and noctilucent clouds
  Aurora
Image Processing
  Star trails: stacking photos
  Milky Way / Star points and Aurora
Resources
results.name: Lecture: Astro-landscapes - Photographing stars, trails, Milky Way and Aurora

ticket is $20

from their website

Our concerts are presented once or twice a month, usually on Saturday nights from September to May. In September 2001 the coffeehouse moved to the First Universalist Society meetinghouse, 262 Chestnut St, Franklin. Doors open at 7:30 PM and all concerts start at 8:00 PM unless otherwise noted. All concerts are non-smoking and alcohol free.In addition to the excellent music, Circle of Friends is known for its gourmet desserts which vary from concert to concert, but typically include several varieties of cheesecake, carrot cake, fruit pies, trifles, tortes, and mousses. You get the idea; don't have dessert before you come! Coffees, teas, soft drinks, water, and cider are also usually available.

This venue is handicap accessible

Purchase tickets online at BrownPaperTickets.com. Tickets can also be purchased at the door.

The annual FSSGB members' concert is always a popular event. Our members perform songs which range from traditional ballads to original compositions, and from instrumental to a cappella pieces. Some of the instruments that have been played at this concert in the past include violin, cello, banjo, mandolin, guitar, bass, keyboard and concertina. Some FSSGB members who have performed at this event have gone on to have successful performing careers, such as Elijah Wald, Mark Ryer, Fool's Errand and Merle Roesler.

Our hosts this year will be Ellen Schmidt and Paul Beck. They are a talented performers who play out regularly, often accompanied by fellow FSSGB members. Ellen performs as half of Two for the Show (with Jake Kensinger) and Paul performs as half of Ergo Canto (with Lesley Bryant); Ellen also runs several popular local open mics.

results.description:
Even if you don't know what Contra Dancing is, if you can listen and walk you can do it and have a good time.
Chris Ricciotti is the caller and we have DogTown as the band (piano, fiddle, flute +). At the dance you get a partner, lineup, subdivide into groups of 4; the caller teaches the moves, and then the music starts and the caller calls out the moves. You progress down the line with your partner interacting with other pairs of people. Then ~15 minutes later there will be another one with another partner. So you get to dance with everyone in the hall.
$10, $6 for students, or pay what you can afford.
http://www.lcfd.org/jp for more info.
results.name: Let's go to the Gender Free Contra Dance in JP

results.description:
Old School Game Show to Ground Control, commencing countdown, engines on...Calling all you Barbarellas and Buck Rogers to join us for a sci-fi spectacle so spaced out that it could make even Spock laugh out loud. Come be a contestant, audience member or Star...-man, Trek or Wars! We love them all. Just get your sexy intergalactic self to this sure to be insane teleportation to sci-fi hijinks!

We've got special musical guest, a true "man from outerspace," Walter Sickert from Walter Sickert & the Army of Broken Toys!
Get ready to laugh your spaceface off for our featured comic, the great Shaun Connolly!!

OSGS is a live interactive theater experience done with all the pageantry and analog style of a 1970's television game show. The show combines elements of pub trivia, variety specials, and comedy sketches to produce a completely unique trivia experience. Participating audience members play to win fabulous individual game prizes from great local sponsors! It's all the fun of an afternoon spent rolling around in the rumpus room- without the rug burn.

Grab your advanced discounted tickets here (It will cost more at the door): https://www.eventbrite.com/e/old-school-game-shows-intergalactic-radioactive-sci-fi-space-odyssey-tickets-21235171971

After the show your ticket gets you in free for our late night comedy show! It features some of Boston's best standups and special guests!

Pssst, You can join the Alt Trivia Revolution here;
www.oldschoolgameshow.com

Michael D'Angelo
Ginny Nightshade
Will Smalley
Kaitlin Buckley
Nick Chambers
Francesca Villa
Megan Ward
Ethan Marsh
Pat Kearnan
Dale Stones
Sake Toomey
Polly Surely
TerrorTits
and special guest Mary Widow!!!!

results.description:
NOTE:  Season 6 will be led by Senior Percolator, David Petringa.

HTML5 Brunch, our virtual self-study group focused on HTML5, CSS3 and responsive design, is returning for Season 6. During this season we will learn how to use the free and open source Bootstrap framework to quickly build websites that automatically reflect each user’s device and experience, without complex hand crafting.  Basic knowledge of HTML, CSS and some JavaScript is helpful making this an intermediate-level course.


The book we will use is Sams Teach Yourself Bootstrap in 24 Hours which was published on November 14, 2015.

The format of a virtual self-study group is as follows:

• Each participant purchases the same textbook: Sams Teach Yourself Bootstrap in 24 Hours.

• Each participant commits to read two chapters per week (the chapters are short), complete the exercises and post links to your completed work.

• Each participant obtains assistance by posting questions to a discussion area set up on the Boston PHP Message Board for each chapter.  Each participant will receive personal feedback, as well as, a weekly group e-mail update.

• Each participant who completes the book is recognized on the Self-Study Group | Wall of Accomplishment.

Note: There is no classroom instruction. There are no webcasts. There are no scheduled appointments of any kind.

Once you have the book, you simply proceed at a pace that best fits into your current work/life schedule.  You DO NOT need to live in the Boston area to participate.  Invite your friends, family members and co-workers to join in the fun!

How do I get started?

• Become a member of Boston PHP if you are not already a member. Simply click: Join us!

• Register for HTML5 Brunch, Season 6.  Simply RSVP: Yes

• Purchase a book (the only program cost). Simply visit Amazon.com and order Sams Teach Yourself Bootstrap in 24 Hours in one of two formats -- paperback or Kindle.

When your book arrives, start your virtual learning by reading one chapter at a time, completing the exercises and posting a link to your completed work.

FAQs:

Q: How long will the course last?

A: We will cover 24 chapters (two per week) in the book starting Sunday, February 28 and ending Saturday, May 21.  Refer to the HTML5 Brunch, Season 6 -- Master Discussion List for specific dates.

Q: Do I have to wait until Sunday, February 28 to begin?

A: No need to wait! Feel free to begin as soon as you obtain a copy of your book.  Simply post a message on the Introduce Yourself: HTML5 Brunch, Season 6 message board once you receive your book so that we can gauge participation. Then, proceed at a pace that best fits your current work/life schedule.

Q: Do I have to live in Boston to participate?

A: Not at all. This program is virtual. We have successful graduates from many states and even have graduates from countries in Europe and Africa.

Q: What if I have additional questions?

A: Simply post a reply below and you will receive a response.

Let's Do Brunch!

David Petringa
Senior Percolator

Gene Babon
Chief Percolator
results.name: HTML5 Brunch, Season 6

venue.name: The New England Center for Homeless Veterans

results.description:
I volunteer a couple of times a month serving lunch at the shelter. Great group of men and women who have served our country and have come back needing a little help. The Center, which was started by a Veteran, provides housing, health care, social services, food, as well as a multitude of other services for our returning heroes. They have volunteer groups come in on weekends and do breakfast service. We don't provide the food, just smiles and friendly faces. The serving starts at 7:15am and we would be done by around 9.  We have gone as a group several times and hope to keep this up monthly, there's a limit to 6 servers each time. It's really a wonderful time. Some of the ladies asked about baking/bringing something. I also spoke with the head of the kitchen....just avoid things with nuts because of allergies. Hope to see you all then! We can carpool, it's near the Orange line and if you drive in you can park right in front. Also remember a hat, you need to have your head/hair covered to serve.

 My telephone number if you have any questions or have a last minute change to status is[masked]

2 things:
1. Since this is a popular event, I'd like to ask that you only sign up only if you are able to get up early on a Sunday.  There will be several Sundays throughout the year I'll actually take myself off as well so that opens up one spot. On the days I cook, I'll also open it up to have 7 servers so that more can come.
2. To prevent the # of no shows we've had, I'm going to just let everyone know that if you know show, I will remove you from future volunteer opportunities with the Center. I've hated the times when due to no shows, the Vets have had to step in to help, especially because there are often individuals that were on the wait list and didn't have the opportunity to show. If you cannot attend, please RSVP no ahead of time, or at the very least, just call or text me if you aren't well the morning of the shift, just so I know and can get them to provide help when I get there. My telephone # is[masked]-1526. Those letting me know that they can't make a day ahead of time won't be considered a no show.

Thank you for your ongoing support. I appreciate it and I know that the Veterans do as well.
results.name: Volunteer and serve breakfast at the New England Center for Homeless Veterans

results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]

=====


Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike to two of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Wildcat and Wildcat D. We will use Nineteen Mile Brook Trail and Wildcat Ridge Trail to summit Wildcat and then we will follow the ridge to Wildcat D. From there we will descend the Polecat Ski Trail. There is a $10 mountain access fee required by the ski area to use their trails - we will purchase these passes in the morning so bring a way to pay.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

RSVPs close 24 hours before the event.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 10 people. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you. 

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 8 miles and climb about 3,200 feet. It should take an average hiker about 5 hours 45 minutes to complete (this duration does not include time for breaks). This event is considered INTERMEDIATE because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/20-Mt-Wildcat-4422--40-Wildcat-D-Peak-4050

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants. 


Use this link for the current weather forecast:

• http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lon=-71.20141869812011&lat=44.25899905312747#.Vp1tqjawlrU

=== What to Bring === 

Don't wear ANY cotton - this includes your socks and underwear. You will need winter hiking boots - if you wear them in the summer they aren't designed for winter use (e.g. insulation). You will need mountaineering snow shoes. Not all snowshoes are the same - some are designed for steep terrain with potentially deep snow while others aren't. These are the acceptable brands and models:

• Tubbs Flex ALP, Flex VRT, Flex TRK, or Mountaineers.

• MSR Lightening, Revo, or Evo. 

• TSL Symbioz Elite or Expert. 

• Atlas Aspect, Endeavor, or Series 10/11/12.

You will also need traction - while you can bring mountaineering crampons if you want I think all you will need is either Kahtoola Microspikes or Hillsound Trail Crampons. DO NOT BRING IMITATION SPIKES OR ANY FORM OF YAK TRAX.

Use this link for a list of items needed for a winter day hike: 

• </a><a href="http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf">http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet in the northwest corner of the parking lot at the Wildcat Ski area (enter lot and go left). According to Google Maps this spot is about 161 miles from Boston and it should take about 2 hours 59 minutes to drive there. Since this is where we will end the day we will leave a few cars here and drive up the road to start the hike.

Use this link to customize the driving directions:

• https://goo.gl/maps/VZx9jH9K6LM2

</a>

While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the <a href="http://www.hikesafe.com/">Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

results.description:
Please read the following description carefully. 

              View of Concord River from the River trail

Carlisle's Foss Farm Conservation Area is located on Route 225 in Carlisle, about a quarter mile west of the Concord River. It links to a 7+ - mile trail network that includes the adjacent Great Meadows National Wildlife Refuge and O'Rourke and Greenough Conservation Areas. These trails meander through the upland forest and ring the perimeter of the fields by way of several long loop routes along the banks of the Concord River.   

Evidence of Native American settlements has been found at Foss Farm.  Artifacts from 3600 to 4100 years ago have been retrieved and there is a documented Native American site registered with the State of Massachusetts.

                                  Greenough Pond What you need to know:

Terrain Difficulty: I’ll rate this terrain as “Easy” because it is mostly flat,   Easy hikes are generally suitable for  beginning hikers who keep in fit condition doing other things. Please be sure that you can comfortably handle 8 miles in the snow, ice., broken ground and mud

Remember that the Difficulty Rating is for the terrain; not the hike itself. When determining if a hike is right for you, remember to factor in: terrain, distance, estimated pace, duration, weather prediction, driving time and your fitness level as well as your mood and frustration threshold..

Distance: Approximately 7 miles.

Elevation Gain: Minimal

Hike Time: Estimated 4 hours. However, this is an estimate. Actual times vary greatly according to weather, trail conditions and the group itself. Don't sign up if you've scheduled something later in the day. The Organizer is not responsible for getting you back in time.

Anticipated Pace: 2-2.5 mph or the pace of the slowest hiker

Hike Type:  Loop

There is no way of knowing trail conditions ahead of time. Use your own judgement.

Anyone with recurrent "No Shows" , or who routinely drops out or about whom we have received complaints from fellow Trekkers will not be accepted. If you haven't hiked with us before, add yourself to the list if you can adhere to these basic prerequisites.

Please don't RSVP "Yes" unless you really intend to come. We are committed to being there for you. If you are not equally committed to being there then please don't sign up.

Please do not show up for an event unexpected or unprepared. Bring water (2 liters), hiking boots (not sneakers or trail runners) and lunch/snacks. Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

This is winter hiking season. Bring your microspikes (not YakTrax or Stabilicers) even if it hasn't snowed. Ice can persist in thicker woodlands

Read "Winter Day Hiking Essentials"in the Pages before signing up  all winter hikes in cold weather conditions.


We hike in light rain or light snow, but heavy rain or snow or any  extreme weather that renders hiking and/or driving conditions hazardous cancels.

This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the lead, stay together, stop at junctions or summits, and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own.

NO DOGS and NO GUESTS are allowed on hikes. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event.

Please remember that your Event Organizers  are volunteers, the event is free and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you are expecting Daniel Boone as your leader, you’re barking up the wrong tree. If you need everything to run perfectly, this hike is not for you.

Short Version: This not an event for high-maintenance individuals.

By signing up and/or attending this hike you agree to the Liability Waiver Below:  

Remember: Your Event Organizers  are volunteers. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code described at <a>www.hikesafe.com;</a> you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason.

If you are offering or need a ride, post that on the message board. However, when responding please do so privately by clicking on the person's profile pick and clicking the "message" link.

Please keep your arrangements private and  off the Message Board/ For your safety don't post your phone number on it.

For Driving Directions go to:

http://www.meetup.com/Bay-State-Hiking-Meetup/events/219805158/

results.description:
An introduction to Boudoir Photography

Over the past ten years there has been a massive increase in the number of people wanting Boudoir photographs. Knowing how to organize and execute a professional boudoir shoot has become a lucrative skill.

In this mix of lecture and practical work with a professional model you will also learn  how to organize and set up a safe and comfortable space for a shoot.

You will also learn the techniques and skills required to build a repertoire of poses and shots that will have your clients coming back  fro more.

In view of the high cost of hiring professional models and so as to keep the cost to the members as low as possible this workshop is not available as part of the free pass system. However, free pass holders can take 50% off the cost when RSVPing online. Just edit the amount on the PayPal page.

Because of the nature of the class it is limited to just 6 attendees and the cost is $175.
results.how_to_find_us: Enter through the EMTS Inc door and head to the second floor.
results.name: Introduction to Boudoir Photography

results.description:
NOTE: This is a continuation of  the classes started on Sunday, February 7th.


This is a 4 week course. If you RSVP for this date you are RSVPing for the complete 4 week course. Please only RSVP if you are committed to attending to the whole series.


This course introduces students to the basic principles of 3D modeling, such as how to navigate in 3D space, what 3D models are made out of, and how to create simple forms and objects. The software used will be Sketchup, a free program that is excellent for beginners and professionals alike. Students will learn the ins and outs of the program, from basic techniques to advanced modeling concepts. This series is for people who have not already taken a 3D modeling class at HATCH.


Requirements:


• A free copy of Sketchup. 

• A CAD-capable laptop or desktop. The computer must have a discrete graphics chip or a very new (last three years) onboard graphics chip.


• A three button (minimum) mouse.


• You must be an experienced Windows or Mac user.


• You should be able to utilize keyboard shortcuts and understand how to use computer file systems.


*If you need a laptop please contact the organizer, we have six laptops available for use. We prefer that you use your own for this class.*

If you are bringing your own computer, please pre-load Sketchup Make. You can download it from <a>www.sketchup.com.</a>
results.how_to_find_us: We're located in the Arsenal Project (formerly Arsenal Mall). Park in the lot near Old Navy entrance, you'll see a big yellow-green sign over the doors. HATCH is between Pearle Vision and Game Stop.
results.name: Introduction to 3D Modeling (4 week class)

results.description:
Hi Soccer Comrades! 

Sunday is going to be another unusually warm for February.  Pleas come and kick the ball around for an hour or so beginning at 10:00 AM.  We will do this at the turf field of Belmont High School, as we did last week and a few weeks ago.  We have no official claim to the field, so hopefully nobody will kick us off.  A few things to remember:

This is the "kinder and gentler" friendly, coed, game for people of all ages and nobody should get too serious: we want to avoid any injuries.

Each player should bring a WHITE shirt and a BLACK or DARK BLUE shirt, so as to make team formation easy.  Please wear shin guards. This is a friendly game but we want to avoid accidental injuries. Cleats are recommended.

Somebody should bring a ball and some cones to mark the field.  (I always do, but I hate everybody to rely on me).

Everybody should bring some water or something to drink, even in this cold weather.

You can find the location at Google Maps with the link: https://www.google.com/maps/@42.39523,-71.1674112,17z

The turf field is located just to the right of the Viglirolo Skating Rink

results.description:
Dear Boston Culture Lovers,

Some of you already know that Johnny D's is closing its doors forever in March. Please join me to enjoy one last jazz brunch at Johnny Ds.  

http://johnnyds.tunestub.com/event.cfm?id=227639&cart 

Meeting time is set for 10 am sharp!

I would usually prefer to meet a little later, however since we are a group and this a popular venue, it has been strongly advised that we meet early so we can sit together as a group.

Please understand that it is not fair to ask those who have arrived early to wait for late comers.

If you are late, I can not guarantee that you will be able to join the group.

Please plan ahead and allow yourself extra travel time to accommodate possible delays in traffic, parking, and public transportation delays. The Davis Square T (subway) stop on the Red Line is located across the street from Johnny D's.

Please only reserve "yes" if you are definitely attending.

This is a space limited event and a false confirmation will deny someone else from attending. If you fail to show up without showing me a common courtesy of communication, you will be at risk of being removed from the group.

Lastly, please be financially prepared to pay for your meal including taxes and tip.

I look forward to meeting new and familiar faces.

Happy New Year!

Joana

results.description:
Greater Boston Oasis meets every week for engaging speakers, live musicians, and the opportunity to connect with the community. Details of the speakers, musical guests, etc. will be posted in the individual meetups as they are confirmed.

Doors for the event open at 10:00 AM for coffee and conversation, with the program starting at 10:30. We hope to see you there!

=========================================

Oasis meets in the Teen Center at the YMCA. To find the room, enter through the lower entrance (on Dartmouth Street, by the swimming pool), and follow Oasis signs from the front lobby to the Teen Center on the second floor. (Note: the stairwell to the Teen Center is NOT the stairwell in the front lobby. That is Stairwell A. The Teen Center is located at Stairwell B, next to the Yoga Studio. Oasis volunteers will be available to help provide assistance, and signage will be posted.

=========================================

Greater Boston Oasis is a secular community dedicated to providing for the human need for social and intellectual community, for those people who may not want or be able to have those needs met in a church or other faith-based community. 

Our Core Values are:

People are more important than beliefs


Reality is known through reason


Meaning comes from making a difference


Human hands solve human problems


Be accepting, and be accepted

Atheist or agnostic, freethinker or skeptic, deist or theist, all those with whom those values resonate are welcome to celebrate the human experience.
results.how_to_find_us: Follow signs from the entrance to the Teen Center room. Use the Dartmouth Street entrance, and head to Stairwell B. Teen Center is on the 2nd floor.

Website: <a>http://joesamerican.com//</a>;

Meeting Location: Please meet near the Host Station.  If you arrive after we are seated the Host will direct you to our table.

Host(s)/Organizer(s): Angela and Andrea (Reservation is under Andrea and Meetup.)

Min/Max: Minimum of 6 people 48 hours prior to the event.  Maximum of 12.

Guests: 1 Adult (21+) per Member
Price Range: The Brunch Menu is less than $14 which does not include alochol.

Cash Only Policy: Please bring cash! Paying for our meals in cash allows us to avoid the confusion of having the waitstaff run multiple credit card slips and generally helps to keep things simpler for everyone.

Cost/Fees:  There are currently no costs or fees associated with this event aside from paying for your food and beverages.  

RSVP Deadline: 2/28/16 by 9am (2.5 hours prior)

Inclement Weather Reschedule Date: Sunday, March 13th

No-Show Policy:  People who RSVP "Yes" to events are expected to exercise common sense and common courtesy. That means making your best effort to keep any commitments that you make, but if necessary doing your best to notify the Event Organizer or (preferably, if it's the day of the event) the venue if something comes up after the RSVP deadline. If you find yourself unable to attend an event that you've RSVPed "Yes" to and you cannot either change your RSVP or let the venue know, please do contact the Event Organizer when you're able to, just to let us know that you're okay and that you're still interested in attending events.  Please be advised that any Assistant Organizer (AO) or the Group Organizer (GO) can remove a member from Social Fun who has 3 No-Shows in the past 3 months.  Additionally, Organizers may disallow members with 2 or more "No Show" marks from attending their events.  **Please keep in mind that the restaurant is expecting the number of people who RSVP Yes to attend and if we show-up missing 1 or 2 people it has an adverse affect on the server and the restaurant as they plan for the number in the reservation and if there's a Waitlist (WL) then you are taking away a spot for someone else if you do not change your RSVP when you are no longer able to attend.**

Hey, please attend if you say you are going to do so.  Please change your RSVP or, if you can't because it's too late to do so, please do one of the following cuz it's the nice thing to do.

-call the restaurant,

-post a comment, or 

-message one of the hosts. 


~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Parking: Free and ample parking at the mall/in front of the restaurant. 

Directions/Location Overview:  Conveniently located inside the South Shore Plaza right off Route 93 @ Exit 6 and accessible by bus.  Please see website above.

results.description:
Join SURJ Boston and White Folks for Racial Justice at this brunch.  Both groups are about engaging white people in racial justice work, and anyone is welcome to attend.

From the Facebook event:

Through a few structured activities to facilitate story-sharing, reflection and connection, we’ll also have a chance to co-create new knowledge and learn community-based wisdom. Come for the company, the conversation and the support.

Our intentions:

• We create with each other a welcoming racial justice culture

• We are present with each other, deepening relationships and community

• We support each other, to grow and be accountable in our work for racial justice

• We learn from each other, in dialogue around key questions in our movement

•  We connect our work with something larger than ourselves, tightening the orbits of the many folks and groups doing racial justice work

THIS IS A POTLUCK! PLEASE BRING FOOD TO SHARE.

Accessibility information: there are a few stairs to get into the house, and we will be on the first floor.  There are no pets.  Please be in touch if you have particular needs.

REMINDER:  DUE TO SCHOOL VACATION WEEK, the staff at Holliston Meadows has asked us to reschedule our Small Doggy PlayDate to Sunday, February 28, 1:00-2:30 p.m.

Please update your RSVP if you are unable to attend. Otherwise, we will see you on Sunday, February 28. If you haven't RSVP'd yet and would like to attend, please RSVP now.  We look forward to seeing you on Sunday, February 28!

Nancy, Amy and Bella

----------------------------------------------------------------

Small Doggy Playdates is conveniently held at The Meadows Pet Resort and Spa in Holliston, 140 Summer Street. We meet mostly every 3rd Sunday of the month, 1:00 pm - 2:30 pm.


The Meadows is a multi-million dollar pet resort. The resort provides us with a large, clean indoor room with windows, chairs, water bowls, and plenty of room for our small dogs to play and socialize. Your dog can run around and play with others, off leash, in a safe environment.  

• All small and toy breeds are welcome. We look forward to having owners of FRIENDLY, EASY-GOING small dogs (under 20 lbs), with GOOD DOGGY MANNERS come play and make new friends. Please be sure your small dog(s) is healthy, clean, spayed or neutered, flea-free, and up-to-date with shots. If your pup(s) shows aggression or excessively barks towards others, you may be asked to leave.

• Due to increased participation at our PlayDates in Holliston, parking has become limited. The Holliston Meadows staff has asked us to please park directly across the street at Fatima Shrine where there is ample FREE parking for all. 

• Please refrain from feeding your dog treats or snacks during the PlayDate as some dogs are allergy-prone or on special diets. Their Moms and Dads will greatly appreciate this.

results.description:
It's the queerest time of the year!


[FREE AND OPEN TO ALL]

The Meeting Point and Pleasure Pie invite you to LEAP with us this February 28th. We are having our winter celebration combined with HAIR: The Art Show. In exaltation of the longest shortest month, we invite you to join us to connect, network, snack, see/make art, and play together.


There will be:

- A good & bad hair experiences ceremony and discussion where you can reflect, process and share about all of your hairy feelings!

- A felt craft station with Goddess Cecilia so you can make and decorate mini sculptures and body part representations. Googly eyes will abound. 

- A zine-making station where you can make a hair-themed mini-book using magazine cut outs, glitter gel pens, a typewriter, and more! No experience or artistic ability needed.

- Glitter and hair coloring stuffs for you to get super fab with your eyebrows, facial hair, and head hair!

- A hair-tastic selfie stick-style photobooth with all sorts of fun wigs and prop options!

- A raffle with awesome prizes including private yoga sessions, $25 gift certificates for Liz's Hair Care, and 30-minute massages at Imani massage!

- Everything you've ever wanted!!!


Of course we'll have snacks. What event is complete without snacks?!

This is for people of all genders, races, ages, sexual orientations, etc.

Want to submit your art, and/or hair?

It’s not too late to bring HAIR - your own, someone else’s, and/or a work of art. If you want to contribute to the show or perform something, please contact [masked] ASAP. We welcome all styles of art; no worries about sticking to one format or being outside of the box.

Accessiblity info: 

This event is taking place at The Meeting Point, a social justice-based healing center in Jamaica Plain. The space is wheelchair accessible and has gender-neutral restrooms.

When attending please let an organizer know you heard about the event from the Pleasure Without Borders Meetup. Thanks!

There's also a Facebook event! Feel free to invite your friends :)
results.name: Leap Year Celebration and HAIR: The Art Show

results.description:
The Good Mother Myth: Redefining Motherhood to Fit Reality" is a collection of honest essays that explores the challenges and joys of motherhood. Even if you don't get to finish it, please join us!

From Amazon: In an era of mommy blogs, Pinterest, and Facebook, The Good Mother Myth dismantles the social media-fed notion of what it means to be a "good mother." This collection of essays takes a realistic look at motherhood and provides a platform for real voices and raw stories, each adding to the narrative of motherhood we don't tend to see in the headlines or on the news.

From tales of mind-bending, panic-inducing overwhelm to a reflection on using weed instead of wine to deal with the terrible twos, the honesty of the essays creates a community of mothers who refuse to feel like they're in competition with others, or with the notion of the ideal mom--they're just trying to find a way to make it work. With a foreword by Christy Turlington Burns and a contributor list that includes Jessica Valenti, Sharon Lerner, Soraya Chemaly, Amber Dusick and many more, this remarkable collection seeks to debunk the myth and offer some honesty about what it means to be a mother.

http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1580055028?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00
results.name: Let's meet for coffee and discuss "The Good Mother Myth"

Dr. Cobb is an educator and writer for New Yorker; Associate Professor of History and Director of the Institute for African American Studies at University of Connecticut.

results.description:
While the electronic version is good, the live version is even better!

The original Through the Ages is one of the best games out there (currently ranked #5 on BGG). The reimplemented version has better art, changed rules for military, and new or altered cards.

In Through the Ages, you take your civilization from the age of antiquity through the modern age, electing leaders, building wonders, colonizing new lands, causing or defending aggressions, etc. The game is very strategic. One of my favorite parts is that there is no map, so you don't get a disadvantage just because you're in bad part of the map or your neighbor is happens to be the strong one.

New players are welcome. If you've never played before, there is a learning scenario we can do first. Thus, any new players should arrive at noon (two hours earlier) to learn the rules and play out the introduction scenario.

Alerts: I have cats (in case you have allergies) and I'm on the fourth floor (no elevator).
results.name: LIVE Through the Ages: A NEW Story of Civilization

results.description:
From 2 to 4 PM we will have a high intermediate level meetup at the Cambridge Recreational Center in Cambridge. This game is for Yankee C- and above level only. Players are required to know how to play a 6-2 and 5-1 formation.

If you'd like to play, please do the following:

1. Send an email to Wing using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=3198724

In the email, confirm that you know how to play in a 5-1 or 6-2 offense, and mention your preferred position (if any).

Players will be added to the list to fill up positions. This game is intended for Yankee C/C- and above players (or equivalent), and people who have not been no-shows at previous meetups. There is a strict cap to make sure everyone gets lots of playing time.

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email.

The cost of the meetup will be $5. Please pay the organizer when you arrive before the meetup starts. The money goes to cover the cost of the court rental. The entrance to the gym is on Cambridge Street opposite Harvard Market. The nearest intersection to the entrance is Cambridge Street and Roberts Road. The nearest T stop is Harvard Square. The gym is about a ten minute walk from the T stop. Parking near the school on Sundays is generally easy to find, as meters and residential parking rules are generally not enforced on Sundays (parking signs should say "EX SUNDAY" or similar).
results.name: Cambridge High Intermediate (Yankee C/C-) Indoor Volleyball

results.description:
From 2 to 4 PM we will have a low intermediate level meetup at the Cambridge Recreational Center.

Low Intermediate - Players possessing the fundamentals and are able to serve, bump, and set the ball consistently. Players are working on improving passing ability and proficiency at attacking. Players should be familiar with 4-2 formation (middle front setter). 

Spots will be filled in until the meetup reaches capacity at 12, with effort made to keep the level of play consistent from week to week.  The waitlist is limited to 6 people.

INSTRUCTIONS: If you'd like to play, please do the following:

1. Low-intermediate & Intermediate players send an email using this link to Anja: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=128841672

There is a strict cap to make sure everyone gets lots of playing time. Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. 

The entrance to the gym is on Cambridge Street opposite Harvard Market. The nearest intersection to the entrance is Cambridge Street and Roberts Road.


If you show up at the game but do not have a "Yes" RSVP, you will not be guaranteed to get playing time.


* Please be serious about RSVP's. If you RSVP "Yes" and don't show up, it means you have prevented someone else from attending. Also, please change your RSVP if you find out you can't play, as soon as possible. Changing the RSVP a few hours before the game time means that there will be less people who can play, as most people prefer some advance notice that there are spots available.

Anyone who changes their RSVP the day of the meetup will be counted as a no show.

results.description:
18xx games are about railroads: building track and running trains for profit. 18xx games are also about a stock market, and the skullduggery between various robber barons as they try to build, thwart, take over, or bankrupt companies. But, they can take quite a while to play. We play with poker chips and emphasize a "ready to play" culture (meaning you're ready to act when your company is up). Games have generally taken from 2 hours (via bankruptcy) to 6 hours (to the end) with the average around 5 hours, even with new players. The more you plan in advance, the faster the game (of course, many times the other robber barons thwart your plans!)

You will need to be ready to start right at the starting time, or very close to it, because the game is so long. We also are splitting into two games quite frequently now so being early is better so we can decide which 18xx games to play and then have to set them up, unless we ALL can come to a pre-arrangement in the comments.

New players are welcome although we strongly suggest familiarizing yourself with the basic rules and concepts first. A brand new player will need 20 to 40 minutes of rules explanation before they play. The game really isn't overly complex, rules-wise, it's just long with lots of decisions. It is a little fiddly sometimes, though.

Due to some late arrivals in prior months, we will emphasize: If you're over 15 minutes late and have not made arrangements with one of the tables, you are probably only going to be a mere spectator, unless there is a game doing a rules explanation, you know that 18xx variant well, and can make it before it starts. If you're much later you probably won't be able to join a game at all. It usually takes us all afternoon and well into the evening to play one game of 18xx. Even our more "experienced" tables usually drop four or five hours into a single game (or more; last month we didn't finish either 1835 or 1830 until 9:30 PM or later). It is rare that there is a second game.

Also since we usually know the people in the week or so prior it will be good at that point if we can sort out what games we want to play in advance. While it's no guarantee we can break down that way, knowing to set up something in advance is SUPER helpful and time saving. Setting up and teaching a new 18xx variant can take an hour or more and the games are quite long as it is, so every little bit helps. What you need to know about 334 Mass Ave:

-Press 999 on the intercom and security will let you into the building
-You must sign in at the security desk with a picture ID
-Take the elevator down to level "A." Exit the elevator to your left and the community room will be ahead on your right, next to the laundry room.

Session would start at 2 PM. Please note your availability in the comments. February is looking to be a particularly tricky month.
results.name: Train Hard 2: Train Harder (February 18xx Event)

results.description:
Well, we had a grand total of one - me! - at our first meeting.  But that was the torrential downpour day, so I just had a macaroon, a cappuccino and made a giant list of books I want to read. 


In order to get the ball rolling, I'm just going to be undemocratic and choose the first book.  Then we can discuss book options at the end of the first meeting.  Drum roll, please.....first book will be Americanah by Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie.  Let's meet same time and place - - Paul Bakery in Burlington at 2:30 on Sunday, Feb. 28.  There is plenty of parking and seems to be a lot of table space at the bakery (or maybe it was just empty because of said downpour...). 

Other books on that giant list include:

Marlon James, A Brief History of Seven Killings (won the Man Booker Prize)

Looking for Transwonderland: Travels in Nigeria by Noo Saro-Wiwa


WG Sebald

Amitav Ghosh, I've read Sea of Poppies and loved it, would love to read others in his trilogy (why does everyone always write trilogies?)

Murakami (I've not been brave enough to dive in here yet!)

the new Salman Rushdie, or revisiting old classics like Midnight's Children

Elana Ferrante? (Why is everyone talking about her?  Why do the cover of her books look like romance novels?  Is this a fad or a life changing author?)

Most of these are new, but also older books and established authors like Cisneros, Allende, Zadie Smith, Kiran Desai, V.S. Naipul, Margaret Atwood, etc.

PLEASE bring your book lists and must reads to this first meeting or email them to me.  We can work up a list to read for the club, or even a giant recommendation list to post for anyone who can't attend....

Cheers,

Kelly

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

WHAT: ASL Weekly Social
WHEN: EVERY SUNDAY 
TIME: 4:00-6:00PM
WHO: ANYONE is welcome to come by and have a conversation in ASL
WHY: To socialize, have fun, and enjoy chatting in ASL
WHERE:  Panera Bread in Porter Square Shopping Center

NOTE: Every once a while, the location may change. PLEASE look on the website each week for confirmation. THANKS!


To get to the Meetup, take the RED LINE stop OUTBOUND TO ALEWIFE, and stop at PORTER SQ. Panera Bread is right next to Dunkin Donuts. If you're driving, you can park on the street for free on Sundays!

Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

Don't be afraid or shy if you're not "perfect" at ASL, because being "perfect" is not the point of this group. No one expects that everyone will be at the same level, and none of us mind slowing down or repeating what we have signed so that everyone understands.

We all laugh WITH one another as we fumble along, mess things up, and start over again. This isn't an ASL class, since none of us are certified ASL teachers, so there's really no pressure or expectation--other than that we all use ASL to communicate. We all learn from one another!

IF you've taken an ASL/Sign Language class before (or have had exposure to someone who uses the language) and know the basics (alphabet, numbers 1-20, and even a small vocabulary of signs ), then join us to get your fingers, hands, face and body moving, ASL-style!

IF you haven't taken an ASL class, or don't know the basics, don't be discouraged ... you can come along anyway and learn by watching, and gradually, participating. We have lots of resources that we can suggest for learning ASL from a qualified teacher or authentic source, such as books, online classes, and local classes at various locations near Boston.

If you can, "officially" RSVP, even if the RSVP is "No," so that we know who is definitely going to come.

It will be great to see folks!

Sean
results.how_to_find_us: We will be there signing our beautiful language to inspire all of you!

results.description:
Give yourself the gift of relaxation and rejuvenation with a wonderful 90 minute gentle yoga and meditation class.

True relaxation is experienced by the body and mind when little or no energy is consumed. It is Nature's way of recharging. Since every action, conscious or unconscious, uses stored energy, relaxation is necessary for good health and peace of mind. Without proper relaxation the body and mind become overworked and inefficient.

When the mind is constantly bombarded by stimuli, it becomes overloaded and exhausted. We may be unaware that we are doing it, but by thinking and worrying we are using up tremendous amounts of energy. The tension put on the mind by worries can use more energy than physical work.

Yoga retrains the body to relax and can calm the mind which leads to inner peace.

This class is for beginners and experienced yogi's.  Chairs are available for those who may need to sit during this class.  Please bring your own yoga mat, water and a blanket or pillow for meditation.

results.description:
Join the oldest established permanent floating Community Walk in Cambridge and Environs.  Join the Community Walkers and walkers from five other meetup groups.   Let's join 20+ others from six other walking groups for:

Since May 2012, there has been a regular walk around Fresh Pond at about an hour before sunset. Frequently, 20-25 walkers turn out for this walk, and you can too. There are a whole bunch of regulars, along with some new people.

We'll go out to dinner at a local pub or chinese restaurant - you can get a decent dinner for under $10.

Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there. We'll be next to the bridge, on the pond side of Huron Ave,at the intersection of Aberdeen Ave.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

Shangri La is located at 149 Belmont Street, Belmont - please let the host know if you're coming, so we can get the right sized table.

results.description:
<a>Want to make something beautiful to hang in your window, give as a gift, or even make your own decorations for a special event? (I decorated my wedding with them!) Do you like scrapbook paper but don’t have a good excuse to buy it? Enjoy origami? Glue guns? Come learn to make kusudama!</a>

Kusudama are modular paper flowers made by folding square or rectangular pieces of paper using origami techniques and then assembling them into flowers or balls with glue or tabs + pockets. They can be simple or complicated to assemble but they are all lovely in the end.

Please come learn to make Kusudama! We will provide paper, glue and instructions, and you will provide your hands and patience (it can take some time to fold 30-60 pieces of paper!). Materials cost donations are appreciated.

The standard popular kusudama model made up of 5-pointed flowers and joined with will be taught. Some alternative kusudama models will be available to look at and youtube is available for the more adventurous who want to learn some more complicated models. Models I (Lisa) am familiar with and could refresh are “Electra” “Esmeralda” and  “Great Stellated Dodecahedron”.

If you wish to fully assemble a kusudama during the event, please be sure to show up early enough to complete it, or you will need to have materials at home to finish. It can take a couple of hours to make one depending on how fast you produce the units.

The event will be held at Lisa’s home in Belmont. To come by T take the 73 from Harvard square (the 71 also stops fairly close). Plenty of non-permit on street parking for those who drive in. Event is on the 3rd floor and is not wheelchair accessible. Please plan accordingly.
results.name: Let's make Kusudama!

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

http://atwys2016bostonspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.
results.name: Speeddating Ages 40-52 - SOLD OUT FOR WOMEN

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

results.description:
Sun 02/28/2016, 5:00 pm - 6:15 pm


We all have some anger in our hearts. It corrodes every relationship, from the relationship we have with ourselves, to relationships we have with our families, colleagues and friends. Have you ever asked yourself the question; is it possible to live without anger and to be peaceful?

In this evenings program we will explore how to heal the wounds of our anger-driven habits and learn to live a life of inner peace.

results.description:
You are invited to an Academy Awards Party tonight! Let's watch with Boston Albanians the Oscar Nominated movie "Shok" and then turn on the TV at 6.30 pm to The Oscars and cheer the Albanian actors and producers as they walk on the red carpet and create with their hands the Albanian eagle. This is the first Albanian movie nominated for an Oscar and we have a good chance of winning. 

If you care to watch it with us, please contact Erin K. at (978) 395-7020. 

Oscar Nominated Albanian movie "Shok" can be found on youtube if you speak Albanian and Spanish (full movie). If you speak English, find it on I-tunes. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U_jtEixoypk
results.how_to_find_us: Contact Erin K. at (978) 395-7020 or admin@eventalb.com

To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
This is a FREE EVENT!  CALL 781-C-FRIARS for more information.



ST. OSWALD'S DAY

A Saint born on leap year day might often get overlooked, so let's take a close look at this Saint Oswald from England!

The last acts in the life of today's saint make for an amazing story. In truth, they merely underscore the holiness he exhibited throughout his life.

Born into a military family in 10th-century England, Oswald was a nephew of the archbishop of Canterbury, who raised him and played a crucial role in his early education. Oswald continued his studies abroad in France, where he became a Benedictine monk.

Following his appointment as bishop of Worcester, and later as archbishop of York, he founded monasteries and introduced many reforms. He supported—and improved—scholarship at the abbeys he established, inviting leading thinkers in such fields as mathematics and astronomy to share their learnings.

He was widely known for his sanctity, especially his love for the poor. The final winter of his life was spent at the cathedral in Worcester that he so loved. At the start of Lent in February of the year 992, he resumed his usual practice of washing the feet of 12 poor men each day. On Leap Year Day, February 29, he died after kissing the feet of the 12th man and giving a blessing.

The news of Oswald's death brought an outpouring of grief throughout the city.

THE RADIO SHOW "CALLED TO COMMUNION"

We are inviting all our non-Catholic friends especially, along with our Catholic ones, as there will be an opportunity for interactive live radio correspondence on this Internationally broadcast show. Several telephones will be available to call and ask questions about the Catholic Faith, particularly ones that non-Catholics may want clarified or even challenged. "What's preventing YOU from becoming a Catholic?" Perhaps something someone has told you, or maybe you just cannot figure out why the Church teaches something, or indeed if She even does! We are all called to Communion with Jesus Christ and the Holy Church that he founded. We already have at least a couple of our non-Catholic friends attending.

After the show we will pray from Psalms (Evening Prayer from the Divine Office), hold a brief Cooking Class and afterwards enjoy some food together.

Th link for today's Prayer is at the following:

http://divineoffice.org/lent-w03-mon-ep?date=20160229 

Great radio talk-show with Dr. David Anders, a convert to the Catholic Faith. He shares his journey and enlightens us on Fullness of the Truth in the Catholic Church. We'll pray Evening Prayer after the show, maybe even call in during, and consider some local place for a bite to eat afterwards for anyone interested in continuing the day's discussions and friendship in Christ. Walk (just around the corner) to the Faneuil Street Entrance and Ring the Doorbell to Apartment #1. Call 781-C-FRIARS for more information. 

http://www.calledtocommunion.com/2010/09/called-to-communion-welcomes-david-anders/

This is a FREE EVENT! 

This is a FREE EVENT!  CALL 781-C-FRIARS for more information.

We will also plan upcoming meetups with Liturgical Hours, the Monastic Cooking Club, etc., including a "Live the Fast" day with reference to http://www.livethefast.org and formation of "Civic Friars" in conjunction with the Civic Friary® and the new School of Monastic Cooking. Call 781-C-FRIARS for more information. 

Additional Information for hearing the show:

via computer: http://tunein.com/radio/WQOM-1060-s27480/

via Radio Dial: 1060AM

via Network (Station of the Cross):http://www.thestationofthecross.com 

via Website:http://www.thestationofthecross.com/stations/boston/

via Radio Station website: http://www.1060catholic.org/

It is hoped you can attend, but there is great opportunity via the above options through computer, podcasts, etc. to hear the show. Please give us feedback on your experience! Call 781-C-FRIARS

Are you seeking effective marketing strategies?  Do you have limited time and resources?  

The Brookline Chamber of Commerce, the Brookline Interactive Group (BIG), <a>Constant Contact</a> and Nicastro Consultants are sponsoring a series of marketing workshops at BIG.

The 2016 #beamarketer workshops are designed to facilitate and support a dialog among business owners.  Participants will learn how to:

-create a marketing play book

-plan an effective marketing strategy

-implement your marketing strategy

-manage marketing initiatives

You’ll also gain an understanding of your thresholds for when to “do it yourself,” “do it with help” or “have someone do it for you.”  

In this presentation, you will discover the latest changes taking place within the top social media platforms and understand how they will affect social media marketing for the next 12 months. Uncover Facebook’s latest algorithm switch and how it will impact a Business Page’s organic views, and communication style. Discover the newest features LinkedIn is rolling out and how to make them work for you and your business. This presentation will also include the top 5 social media trends predicted for the next 12 months and techniques to incorporate them into your business.

Attendees will walk away with and knowledge of:

-Changes impacting their social media accounts and how to adjust their marketing strategy accordingly

-The latest trends and how to take advantage of them in their current marketing plans


-How to utilize a marketing play book to properly plan their digital marketing and become more organized for the next 12 months

Presented by Heather Jackson of Constant Contact and Doreen Nicastro of Nicastro Consultants. Read about Heather and Doreen at http://business.brooklinechamber.com/events/details/what-you-need-to-know-about-digital-marketing-for-the-next-12-months-866

The modern mammal metropolis of Zootopia is a city like no other. Comprised of habitat neighborhoods like ritzy Sahara Square and frigid Tundratown, it’s a melting pot where animals from every environment live together — a place where no matter what you are, from the biggest elephant to the smallest shrew, you can be anything. But when rookie Officer Judy Hopps (voice of Ginnifer Goodwin) arrives, she discovers that being the first bunny on a police force of big, tough animals isn’t so easy. Determined to prove herself, she jumps at the opportunity to crack acase, even if it means partnering with a fast-talking, scam-artist fox, Nick Wilde (voice of Jason Bateman),to solve the mystery. WaltDisney Animation Studios’ “Zootopia,” a comedy-adventure directed by Byron Howard (“Tangled,” “Bolt”) and Rich Moore(“Wreck-It Ralph,” “The Simpsons”) and co-directed by Jared Bush (“Penn Zero: Part-Time Hero”), opens in theaters on March 4, 2016.
